Here we are, then, on the last day of the UKâ€™s membership of the EU. We fought, we lost, and now weâ€™ve got to live with the consequences.

Which wonâ€™t really start to take effect until the start of next year, of course, because weâ€™ll be in the transition period until then. Until 2021 weâ€™ll still be able to travel freely; there will be no added tariffs on goods; food standards will still be the high ones weâ€™re used to.

Ah yes, food standards. Just the other day I had a realisation â€” no, it was something that I already knew. More a dawning fear of how close a bad thing was. What brought it home was this headline in the Independent: â€œBrexit: US insists chlorinated chicken must be on menu in any UK trade agreement.â€

Obviously no-oneâ€™s going to force anyone to buy or eat chicken, chlorine-washed or otherwise. But remember why chicken in the US is washed in chlorine, and why importing it into the EU is banned: itâ€™s because the food standards are significantly lower than those in the EU. The chlorine washing is to kill off bacteria and make the meat fit for human consumption.

So what that headline means is that a US trade deal could depend on the UK lowering its food standards. Thatâ€™s what Brexit means: our government could choose to lower the standards of hygiene required in food production. Sit with that thought for a while.

There are a couple of good things to think about on this bleak day. Both of those are also from America, and neither has anything to do with Brexit. But Iâ€™ll leave them for later posts. Stay tuned.

I leave you with this delightful snippet of Alex Andreou, on the Remainiacs podcast, suggesting how to cope with today, and the future.

Anyway, the most interesting thing is ligatures for programmers. Take a look at this:

You see that â€œnot equalsâ€ sign? The crossed-out equals that we were taught to write back in secondary school? Thatâ€™s not a character in any normal ASCII typeface. Plus, this is Java: even if it were a character (there is a Unicode character for that symbol), itâ€™s not part of the language. The compiler wouldnâ€™t recognise it.

What that actually is is the standard not-equals of C-based languages: !=. But the font has detected it and replaced it with the more attractive and traditional symbol.

Itâ€™s a setting you can disable, and Iâ€™m not sure Iâ€™ll keep it that way, but itâ€™s impressive and unusual.

items.title: Who the What?
items.content_text:
You probably want to know what I think of the new series ofÂ Doctor Who so far.

It got off to a really strong start with â€˜Spyfallâ€™ part 1. Not least with its genuinely surprising reveal at the end. And then part 2 followed up on it. Not everything made total sense, but what the hell, itâ€™sÂ Doctor Who. There were some complaints about the way the nazis and The Master were handled, and I get that. And it had the memory-wiping thing. But all in all, I found it a strong, promising start to the new season.

And then we got â€˜Orphan 55.â€™

Oh dear. Oh dearie, dearie me. This was, for me â€” Iâ€™m not going to sugarcoat it â€” the worst episode ofÂ Doctor Who ever. At least in the modern era.

The story was confused and confusing, the direction was incoherent, the character motivations made no senseâ€¦ Oh, and the message â€” admirable though it was, to say it was beating us over the head with a stick is to understate how heavy-handed it was.

I thought it must be a first-time writer and director. But no: it was written byÂ Ed Hime, who wrote â€˜It Takes You Awayâ€™ last season, which was very good. And it was directed byÂ Lee Haven Jones, who directed â€˜Spyfallâ€™ part 2, just the week before.

So what went wrong? Hard say, but Iâ€™ve got to hope they pick things up again on Sunday.

items.title: Eyes Full of Tinsel and Fire
items.content_text:
Christmas is the time of year when the devil doesnâ€™t have all the best tunes. The other side gets some of them too.

I love Christmas songs. Not all of them. of course, but many. And that includes some of the Christmas carols. A full choir singing â€˜Hark the Herald Angels Sing,â€™ or â€˜Oh Come All Ye Faithfulâ€™? Iâ€™m there.

The best Christmas songs, though, do belong to the â€” letâ€™s say â€” secular side of things. I have a hierarchy of my personal favourites. Things move around a bit, and very occasionally new ones arrive; and you wonâ€™t be surprised to learn that â€˜Fairytale of New Yorkâ€™ remains unassailable in the top spot.

One of my other favourites is Greg Lakeâ€™s 1975 hit, â€˜I Believe in Father Christmas.â€™ Now, if you havenâ€™t listened to the words too closely â€” written, Iâ€™m surprised to discover, by Peter Sinfield, of whom I had barely heard before researching this â€” you might think itâ€™s a simple celebration of Christmas, set to a jaunty tune, much like Sladeâ€™s â€˜Merry Xmas Everybody,â€™ from a couple of years earlier (and every year since). Itâ€™s not, though. Itâ€™s much darker and more interesting than that:

They sold me a dream of Christmas
They sold me a Silent Night
They told me a fairy story
Till I believed in the Israelite

And that closing couplet:

Hallelujah, Noel, be it Heaven or hell
The Christmas we get we deserve

Lake and Sinfield have argued that itâ€™s not anti-religious or atheistic. Well, you can have your interpretation, guys. I know what I think.

I mainly wrote this because Iâ€™ve wanted to use the line Iâ€™ve stolen as a title for years. And Iâ€™ll leave you with the wishes the song provides:

I wish you a hopeful Christmas
I wish you a brave New Year

I think weâ€™re all going to need some hope and some bravery in 2020.

items.title: The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen: The Tempest by Alan Moore and Kevin Oâ€™Neill (Books 2019, 24)
items.content_text:
The final volume of Mooreâ€™s League stories, and, he says, his final work in the comics medium. If so, itâ€™s not a bad closer.

It occurs to me that a significant portion of his comics output has been built on the work of others. Nothing wrong with that. Indeed, it could be said to be true of all literature, maybe all art. Mooreâ€™s use is more frequent than most, though: The Watchmen characters based on those from old Charlton Comics; Marvelman/Miracleman a revival of Mick Angloâ€™s creation; Promothea digging into mythology and fiction, as I wrote very positively about last year; and so on.

In the League itâ€™s at its most explicit. The main characters are Mina Murray from Dracula, Virginia Woolfeâ€™s Orlando, and Alan Quatermain from H Rider Haggardâ€™s novels (although he isnâ€™t in this volume). Even the subtitle of this one is from Shakespeare.

There is, as I say, nothing wrong with any of that. Itâ€™s like sampling in music: it doesnâ€™t matter that youâ€™re using part of an earlier creation; what matters is what you do with it.

And what Moore and Oâ€™Neil do with everything here is pretty spectacular. I wonâ€™t go into any detail, but suffice it to say that pretty much all the threads from the earlier volumes are tied up, and everything is over at the end. Everything. Well, not everything everything. Not quite.

I wouldnâ€™t start here, though: go back to the beginning if you want to read any of these. Read them all.

Jolyon Maugham QC and the Good Law Project are petitioning Johnson to ask the EU to allow us to have associate EU citizenship, as part of the exit negotiations. I canâ€™t imagine itâ€™ll do much good, but thereâ€™s no harm in signing.

On one level I think theyâ€™re trolling Johnson: suggesting that he might want to â€” or suggesting that thereâ€™s any chance he would â€” appear statesmanlike.

items.title: Calling From London
items.content_text:
Forgetting for a minute the slightly-disappointing conclusion of a 42-year-old story that we spoke about the other day, this month gives us the 40th anniversary of an even more significant creation, for me at least.

The Clash released London Calling in December 1979. Rolling Stone went on to call it the best album of the 80s, but it got a later release in America. And in any case, many wouldnâ€™t have heard it until 1980. 1

Including me. I remember being at school, at the start of a term, so it must have been January, and Watty saying, â€œI envy you: you havenâ€™t heard London Calling yet.â€ That idea of how important the first listen is. Iâ€™ve said similar things myself over the years, about various things.

But honestly, I couldnâ€™t tell you anything about my first hearing. I had probably heard the title track â€” it was a single, after all â€” and I went and bought the album, most likely at John Menzies in Dumbarton (though maybe at Hall Audio, the nearby hi-fi shop, or Woolies, or Boots, who used to sell records in those days). I do know it cost Â£3.99, because the band took a reduction in their royalties so it â€” a double album â€” could be sold at the same price as a single album. Excellent value, for one of the greatest records ever made.

Though I paid for it a couple more times over the years. Someone walked off with my copy during a party at my student flat in Edinburgh. I replaced it with a second-hand copy, probably from Record Shak (sic) on Clerk Street. Though possibly that was much later and in London. I had a tape of it to tide me over. I do know that the replacement cost the same: Â£3.99.

The CD must have cost me a bit more, but I didnâ€™t get that until the 25th-anniversary version, with The Vanilla Tapes, the rehearsal-room recordings of early versions of several of the songs.

I could probably tell you a few things about the 7852 2 times Iâ€™ve heard it subsequently, though. But it would be better for you to listen to it yourself.

And lastly, just a reminder that tomorrow is the 17th anniversary of Joe Strummerâ€™s death.

items.title: The Steep Approach to Garbadale, by Iain Banks (Books 2019, 23)
items.content_text:
One interesting thing about this book that I donâ€™t recall noticing when I read it twelve years ago is that the story itself is the titular approach. We donâ€™t get to Garbadale House until about two-thirds of the way through, and then the rest of it is set there. With a few flashbacks and -forwards thrown in to both sections.

Banksie always plays with form and structure, and this is no exception. Not just the aforementioned directional flashes, but use of different viewpoint characters and tenses. Mostly itâ€™s from the viewpoint of Alban McGill, one of the many members of the Wopuld family. Some scenes are from that of a cousin of his. There are even a couple of instances of promiscuous PoV, or â€œhead-hopping,â€ where we get the thoughts of another character within the same scene.

Also some parts switch to present-tense, while most if it is past. There doesnâ€™t seem to be any obvious function to those switches: itâ€™s not like the tense reflects the timeline within the story. It seems arbitrary, almost random â€” though maybe Iâ€™m missing something there.

None of this harms the story, itâ€™s just worth noting. The strangest of these devices is that there are three or four sections in first-person, from the PoV of a minor character. All the rest is third-person. That gives the impression that this character is more significant than he is. The text in those sections is also rendered with spelling mistakes and grocerâ€™s apostrophes, as if it was the direct transcript of what this relatively poorly-educated character has scribbled down.

Whatâ€™s the point of all that? Iâ€™m not sure. Just writerly games, maybe. I wonder if it suggests that Banks didnâ€™t think the story itself was interesting enough to sustain the narrative, which might be a valid criticism. A well-off family with a secret at its heart has to decide whether to sell its business. The secret comes out, but it doesnâ€™t make much difference. It would be significant to the characters affected, but we hardly see them after the reveal.

Endearing characters, though, and even on a second read (I didnâ€™t recall the secret), it keeps the pages turning.

As I said twelve years ago, â€œIn a book like this, the pleasure is in the journey more than the destination.â€

From The Guardianâ€˜s piece on what we learned in the election about the media:

One Labour MP who nearly lost their Brexit-backing seat told the Guardian that on doorstep after doorstep, people brought up Corbynâ€™s connections with the IRA after seeing memes and images on Facebook: â€œIt was never used by the Tories in the campaign but there was a separate election going on, which was a Facebook-orientated campaign.â€

Maybe this explains the hatred for Corbyn which so mystified me.

The next paragraph is astonishing:

The MP suggested constituents are increasingly overwhelmed by information and unsure what is real and what is not, assuming there is some sort of editing of what goes on Facebook. â€œPeople have a sense that some of this stuff is probably wrong but they have no compass. They would say: â€˜But itâ€™s on Facebook â€“ how can there be something that isnâ€™t true?â€™ They think there are gatekeepers but there arenâ€™t.â€

Emphases mine. Oh my god. How can anyone think that after all thatâ€™s happened? I realise that not everyone is as deeply into tech and politics as I am, but still.

We never had a chance, did we?

items.title: Broken Glass
items.content_text:
Iâ€™ve been feeling kind of sorry for Jo Swinson today. Also for myself, and the whole country, especially underprivileged people, people with disabilities, the young, the old, minorities, the marginalisedâ€¦ Anyone whoâ€™s going to suffer under the new regime.

But Swinson lost her seat by just 149 votes, which must be especially heartbreaking. She always impressed me as someone who knew what she was talking about and was on top of things. She was part of the Cameron/Clegg coalition, which is problematic, but letâ€™s let that go.

Sheâ€™s quoted as saying:

One of the realities of smashing glass ceilings is that a lot of broken glass comes down on your head.

which is great, and sad.

People criticised her for making the Liberal Democrat campaign too presidential, too much about her, and that probably was a mistake. Though would they have criticised a male leader in the same way?

And thereâ€™s the business of promising to revoke Article 50. Which I was and am completely in favour of, even if it can seem undemocratic.1 The problem was not the promise, but the messaging. The story should have been, â€œElect us to government and youâ€™ll give us a mandate to revoke. Give us less power and weâ€™ll work for a second referendum.â€ That was the story: she just seemed to have some difficulty expressing it in clear, simple terms, at least in the debates I saw.

All that said, Iâ€™m still baffled as to what has happened to the country.

  1. it wouldnâ€™t be if handled properly, but itâ€™s too late to go into that now.Â â†©
Itâ€™s 4 in the morning and Gove is telling lies on the telly. This has become masochism â€” actually it did several hours ago â€” Iâ€™ll just listen to wee Nicola, and then go to bed.
Jeez, Jo Swinson loses by 149, in my old stomping grounds. Actually I think the constituency was West Dunbartonshire wherein I grew up, but close enough.
I think Corbynâ€™s stepping down (as he should) â€” or maybe itâ€™s only at the next General Election? Strange phrasing.
Ed Milibandâ€™s still around? And he just scraped back into his seat.

items.title: The Politics We Deserve?
items.content_text:
Well tonight is a fucking disaster. Even if the reality is lower than the exit poll, it looks like itâ€™s going to be a landslide for the Tories. Weâ€™ll get a hard Brexit starting in a month and a half (and taking years and years before it â€œgets done,â€ of course). Weâ€™ll see more privatisation in the NHS. Weâ€™ll see more austerity, I donâ€™t doubt, despite the spending pledges that might have been in the Tory manifesto. And weâ€™ll see moves to restrict what parliament and the courts can do to protect ordinary people.

Our best hope is that Johnson is incompetent, and thatâ€™s not something we should have to rely on.

What is wrong with this country? Why do people continue to vote against not just the interests of the most vulnerable in society, but against their own self interest?

On Twitter a lot of people are blaming Corbyn, and I think theyâ€™re right. I said just the other day that I didnâ€™t understand the dislike; but a thread by @RussInCheshire has helped to clarify my thinking. This regards not so much why people generally dislike him, but why he was ineffectual or worse as a leader. The key points:

People will say â€œthe media is biasedâ€. Yes. But thatâ€™s the environment Labour leaders always operate in. Complaining about it is like trawler captains complaining the sea is wet. Yep. Learn to thrive in those conditions, or get off the boat.

People will say â€œthey treated him worse than any previous leaderâ€. They did. Cos he was shit at working the press, had a history of opinions that could be easily made to look awful, was inept on antisemitism, shifty on Brexit and cantankerous on TV.

People will say â€œno way is he racistâ€. Perhaps. But if people accused me of antisemitism, Iâ€™d be able to clearly defend myself, demonstrate my credentials, and put in place a strategy to stop accusations. He couldnâ€™t. If heâ€™s not antisemitic, heâ€™s inept.

People will say â€œvoters love him in personâ€. Iâ€™m sure. But weâ€™ve been in the age of broadcasting for 80 years. What the hell use is being warm and cuddly to 600 people in a field, when you come over badly to 60 million people on TV?

The thread starts here, but it might be easier to read here, as expanded by the Threader App.

I still donâ€™t understand â€” I never will â€” people who switch from Labour all the way to Conservative. They just vox-popped someone on the telly who used to vote Labour, but â€œcouldnâ€™t, in conscience,â€ vote for them with Corbyn as leader. Fair enough. But she voted Tory. Why go all the way over to the party that diametrically opposes the values she claims to support, when there are other progressive parties, that support some of those values. The party she voted for opposes those values.

Baffling. Utterly baffling.
Itâ€™s not too late to vote, folks. Half an hour to get down to your polling station, get the Tories out, and stop Brexit.

items.title: Fear and Loathing All Over the Land
items.content_text:
The time is almost upon us, and I have The Fear. Or at least, I understand The Fear.

I understand the fear of Brexit; of giving the Tories control, yet again, of the NHS, and of the economy; and of their plans for changing the constitution in all the wrong ways, since I feel it myself.

But despite my problems with Corbyn, I donâ€™t understand the loathing for him. It doesnâ€™t seem to come from dislike of his policies. Some of the people who say they donâ€™t like or donâ€™t trust him seem to be Labour voters, who youâ€™d expect to have similar beliefs. Even if those people have more centrist beliefs, youâ€™d think theyâ€™d be close enough to the partyâ€™s current policies not to be put off totally.

It seems almost to be personal. Do some people dislike him as a person? Strikes me as odd, as he comes across as quite moderate and reasonable to me. To be sure, he can get snappy with interviewers at times, but itâ€™s nothing compared to some people. And at least he doesnâ€™t bluster; doesnâ€™t lie; and always gives the impression that he knows what heâ€™s talking about.

Yet some people say they donâ€™t trust him. Sometimes those same people say they do trust Johnson, even as they acknowledge he lies. Itâ€™s unfathomable.

On tonightâ€™s Channel 4 News they interviewed a guy in Johnsonâ€™s constituency who claimed to be a socialist, but who is going to vote for Johnson this time. They didnâ€™t push him for an explanation.

In the same constituency there was a business owner who had always voted Tory but is not going to this time, because of the way the party has been taken over by the far right. It takes a Tory businessman to recognise what a â€œsocialistâ€ canâ€™t. We are through the looking glass and no mistake.

Anyway, Iâ€™ll be voting Green. I hope everyone reading this will get out and vote on Thursday, for anyone who isnâ€™t the Tories, and to stop Brexit.

items.title: Watchmen on TV
items.content_text:
I succumbed. As I suggested I might.

It felt a little grubby, going to the NowTV site and setting up an account. As you know, Sky TV and I have a history. Or maybe an anti-history, insofar as I am anti everything that their former owner stands for. But the key word is â€œformer.â€ With Comcast now owning it, I can feel a little better about giving them my time and possibly some money.

Still, though: grubby.

But whatâ€™s worse, as a viewing experience, is that their app is the worst video-playback app Iâ€™ve ever used. Itâ€™s fine at all the basics; it even has a ten-second jump back and forward feature, which is good. But! It completely fails at subtitles.

Now, in this era â€” this platinum age of television â€” subtitles are often an essential part of viewing. And that isnâ€™t true just due to my age, because my kids, who are young adults, are at least as likely as us olds to want them on. Mumblecore actors are to blame. Or maybe bad sound on our TV. Or a combination. Doesnâ€™t matter. We watch with subtitles on a lot of the time, and I wanted them on for Watchmen.

But NowTV â€” in its Mac app, at least â€” just canâ€™t handle them properly. They either freeze, so you get the same sentence stuck on the screen for five minutes; or they just get out of sync. Sometimes they rush through minutes of text at a time, as if trying to catch up. In the end I turned them off.

But I watched one episode on my iPad, and the subtitles were fine there. So I guess it is the actual Mac app. The Mac plugged into the telly is an old one. A nine-year-old MacBook Pro, in fact. Iâ€™m impressed that itâ€™s still working, though I did upgrade it at one point.

Anyway, that canâ€™t be the reason itâ€™s bad, because Iâ€™ve also tried it on my 2017 MBP, with exactly the same results.

But what about the programme?

Itâ€™s a sequel to the comic, set around thirty years later. I found the first episode kind of annoying, though Iâ€™m not quite sure why. Too much of it set in the past, maybe? But as weâ€™ve got to know the characters and things have moved along, itâ€™s definitely interesting. Iâ€™ve watched the first five episodes so far. Up to which point itâ€™s kind of a cop show with an unusual background. Cops go masked so that criminals canâ€™t identify them. Criminals go masked too, of course, specifically in Rorscach-style black and white masks.

And thereâ€™s a mysterious old guy who puts on plays reenacting the origin of Doctor Manhattan. Youâ€™ll have guesses about who he is, if you know the source material. Well, one guess.

I like the way theyâ€™ve built on the comic, and are weaving the backstory in. Though I think it must be extremely confusing for anyone who hasnâ€™t read the novel, or at least seen the movie.

My main question (apart from the obvious ones, like whatâ€™s going on with Veidt?) is: why is Laurie using her fatherâ€™s surname? It doesnâ€™t make sense to me that sheâ€™d call herself Blake, instead of Juspeczyck.

Oh, and whatever happened to Dan Dreiberg? I want to see some Nite owl action. Something that looked a lot like the Owlship appeared in the first episode, so maybe heâ€™ll turn up. As, I imagine, will Doctor Manhattan.

items.title: Labour and Antisemitism
items.content_text:
I donâ€™t doubt that many Jewish people are put off voting Labour because of the antisemitic actions of some of its members, and the leadershipâ€™s seeming inability to control or remove those people. Plenty of non-Jewish people are put off by it too.

There are two things I donâ€™t understand.

If there are antisemites in Labour (which, again, does seem to be the case): why and how? Who are these people that have joined a party of the left, a party that has always been anti-nazi, anti-racist, pro equality and human rights â€” who join it, and yet stand in direct opposition to its core values? Itâ€™s like a climate-change denier joining the Green Party.

Further, why now? Why has this blown up in the last couple of years? These invasive members presumably havenâ€™t just joined the party. Itâ€™s hard to imagine that they joined because of Corbyn being the leader.

Unless thatâ€™s exactly what it is. Maybe Corbynâ€™s seeming weakness on responding to the problem. and/or a willful misunderstanding of his stance on Palestine and the government of Israel, has attracted such people to the party. In which case â€” in any case â€” the obvious thing to do is to find them and eject them; just as they can easily eject members who suggest voting for another party.

I see that The Guardian has published an â€œeverything you need to knowâ€ guide on the matter. Which is good, but it doesnâ€™t really answer my questions.

Corbyn has spoken out against antisemitism again. He may have appeared vague on Brexit, but I donâ€™t think he could be any clearer on this.

items.title: The Book of Dust vol 2: The Secret Commonwealth by Philip Pullman (Books 2019, 22)
items.content_text:
You shouldnâ€™t read this book.

Yet.

I broke a personal rule, that goes back to 1982: Never start reading a fantasy series if the final volume hasnâ€™t been published.1 1982 was the year I was reading Stephen Donaldsonâ€™s The Chronicles of Thomas Covenant. The fifth volume (or second volume of the second series) was out, but the sixth and final wasnâ€™t.2 I waited on tenterhooks.3 Eventually the hardback came out, but it was much too expensive for a poor student like me. Luckily, not for another poor student on my corridor, who lent it to me.

I learnt my lesson, back then. More or less: I was reading Harry Potter while it was still being written. But this is one of the main reasons why I never started A Game of Thrones, for example.

But here we are. Two-thirds of the way in to a compelling, thrilling storyâ€¦ actually thatâ€™s not quite right, what with the first volume being prequel. More like halfway through a very long story, and all I can say isâ€¦ not very much without going into massive spoilers.

I like that Lyra is using Silvertongue as her surname: a name she was given, that she earned. There are aspects of the world, of Lyraâ€™s relationship to it, that are surprising, given what she went through in His Dark Materials. But then, it is eight years later, and she has grown up a lot.

Politics and events in the world of the Magisterium sometimes parallel those in our world.

Itâ€™s a lot darker and more adult-themed than the original trilogy. I donâ€™t know if the whole will end up being as legendary or as moving as the original, of course, but at this point, balanced on the fulcrum of change, I like it almost as much.

I lied at the the start: you should read this book. But be prepared for the fact that we might have to wait two years for the conclusion.

  1. At a pinch, if the author hasnâ€™t finished writing it.Â â†©
  2. White Gold Wielder was released in 1983, I see. And I gather that heâ€™s since written a third trilogy, butâ€¦ nah.Â â†©
  3. Well, maybe about five or sixterhooks.Â â†©

items.title: Election Debates: Maybe Better Left
items.content_text:
I watched the election debate between Corbyn and Johnson on ITV. It was unedifying, and not very revealing. Corbyn was, predictably, calmer, more sensible, and less blustering. He needed to answer the â€œWhat way would you campaign in a second referendumâ€ question that Johnson kept going back to, but otherwise he handled it pretty well.

Johnson, of course, is the epitome of bluster, barely gave a straight answer to anything, and went over his allotted time on every question, as well as his opening and closing statements.

I criticise him for that since he was violating the agreed-upon format. But the time-limited questions may have been the worst part of the event. The purpose is to limit bloviation, I suppose, but it seemed like often the chair was cutting the speaker off while they were still trying to make a point. I saw a tweet while it was going on, to the effect that part of the problem in politics is that everything is reduced to soundbites, with no opportunity to go into details. Iâ€™m inclined to agree.

However, much more interesting, and a bettter format, was the interviews, an hour later, with the leaders of the some of the other parties: Jo Swinson, Nicola Sturgeon, SiÃ¢n Berry of the Greens, and, unfortunately, Nigel Farage.

One interviewer, one interviewee at a time, and it was all much more sensible. That is, in part, because of the people involved, of course. The three women were all good, especially Wee Nicola, as we like to call her. But perhaps it wouldnâ€™t have worked so well if Johnson had been in the intervieweeâ€™s chair. Heâ€™d have been havering and talking over the interviewer, no doubt. Though to be fair, Farage managed not to do that, so who knows.

But overall, I think that the debate format is not the best way to present your ideas.

items.title: Kieron's Comic, BrontÃ«'s Book

One of the comics I read is Kieron Gillenâ€™s1 Die, which is about a group of people who get sucked into a fantasy world. The world is based on a role-playing game â€” or at least, it seems to be at first. The other night I started the latest issue, 9. Unexpectedly â€” but not surprisingly â€” Charlotte BrontÃ« turned up as a character (or maybe not, but letâ€™s run with it). The story was about how she and her siblings had created complex fantasy worlds in part as stories for their toy soldiers. And maybe the world of Die is based in part on those.

Imagine my surprise, then, when I woke the next day to hear on the radio news that a tiny book â€” â€œno bigger than a matchboxâ€ â€” written by Charlotte, was being auctioned in France. It is filled with stories of the fantasy worlds created by her and her siblings.

The book has been bought by the BrontÃ« Society. It will be kept in the BrontÃ« Parsonage Museum, where it was created.

Two completely unrelated events, of course, but interesting how things collide.

items.title: His Dark Materials on TV
items.content_text:
Minor spoilers ahead.

I am loving what theyâ€™re doing with HDM1 in the BBC/HBO adaptation. It has just enough variation from the books to keep it interesting (especially since I re-read them recently). Yet it manages not to distort the story in the way that so upset my then-ten-year-old son in the film version of (part of) the first book.

Bringing in the scenes of Lord Boreal crossing to â€œourâ€ Oxford, and finding out about who Grumman is, is inspired. It will have the effect of making more sense of the inciting incident for Will, when he turns up. In the book it was never entirely clear who the people who searched his house were sent by, and why the authorities were interested in him. This way, it will.

Iâ€™m looking forward to next weekâ€™s arrival of Lin-Manuel Miranda as Lee Scoresby.2 And weâ€™ll get Iorek Byrnison, too. Thatâ€™ll be a big test of the CGI.

Which leads me to the only thing that slightly lets it down: Pantalaimonâ€™s default form as an ermine. It looks a little too fake and plasticky to me. Most of the other daemons look fine, so I donâ€™t know why the lead one should be so poor. Maybe itâ€™s because heâ€™s the only one that gets much screen time where he talks.

On that note, two points about Mrs Coulterâ€™s daemon, one which struck me on my recent reread, and the other just tonight. We never learn its name. Nearly every other daemon that gets a mention, gets a name. And it never speaks. Certainly not so far in the TV version, and Iâ€™m fairly sure it never does in the books, either.

Which no doubt tells us something about the character of the woman.

items.title: Watchmen by Alan Moore & Dave Gibbons (Books 2019, 21)
items.content_text:
I like to reread this from time to time, and right now Iâ€™m considering watching the TV version thatâ€™s currently on. Itâ€™s HBO, which means Sky over here, which would traditionally have ruled it out on ethical grounds. But times and corporate ownerships have changed. The Murdochs no longer own Sky TV, so I can let myself watch it.

But then we have the other ethical question, about Watchmen in particular. Which is to say, since Alan Moore feels that he was cheated by DC over the ownership of the creative work, and repudiates all derivative works, shouldnâ€™t we avoid them too? I saw the movie version, but I didnâ€™t get the Before Watchmen spin-offs.

Well, itâ€™s been a long time; Moore and Gibbons must have known what they were signing up for, even if things didnâ€™t go quite as they expected. I recall seeing Moore at a convention in Glasgow in 1985 or 86, where he said, â€œDC are utter vermin.â€ Yet he went on to work with them often after that.

Plus, Iâ€™m already reading Doomsday Clock, which brings the Watchmen universe into the DC multiverse, so personally, that ship has sailed.

How does the story stand up today? Itâ€™s still excellent, I would say. With the obvious weakness of the ending. Though thinking about that, whatâ€™s weak is how preposterous Veidtâ€™s plan is. Accepting that, that part of the story is well executed.

Itâ€™s still one of my favourite comics.

items.title: Northern Lights, The Subtle Knife and The Amber Spyglass by Philip Pullman (Books 2019, 18, 19 & 20)
items.content_text:
His Dark Materials, as I said.

Holy hell, this trilogy is good! I think Iâ€™d forgotten just how good it is.

In the first book we meet Lyra, a wild orphan who lives in fabled Jordan College in a parallel Oxford. Plots and adventures quickly ensue.

The second volume starts with Will, a boy who lives in our world, and who has to run from his home because he has killed someone. How will his story connect to Lyraâ€™s?

And the third builds on everything that has gone before, and a whole lot more.

There are armoured bears, angels, daemons, airships, witches, harpies, the dead, and much else. The fate of worlds hangs in the balance.

If you havenâ€™t read it, you should. You could start watching the TV series instead, but I expect thereâ€™ll be a long wait between the seasons, and the books are right there.

Of course, Iâ€™m going to find myself in a similar position with the sequels. It was eighteen months ago that I read part 1, so presumably we wonâ€™t get the conclusion till some time in 2021.

I like what theyâ€™re doing with the TV series so far. Enough changes to keep it interesting, not enough to spoil it.

items.title: Election Blues
items.content_text:
I donâ€™t fully understand the rationale of the Lib Dems and SNP pushing for an election at this point. No-deal is still firmly on the table, it seems to me, and if the Tories get a big majority â€” or even just an actual majority â€” then we remainers are done for.

Yet Ian Dunt at politics.co.uk describes it at as â€œone last chanceâ€ for remainers. He makes a compelling case. If he hadnâ€™t gone for the election, Johnson could likely have got the Withdrawal Agreement Bill (WAB) through parliament. This way, at least thereâ€™s a chance. A hung parliament, a coalition that gives us a second referendum.

A new Remain campaign that is successful.

Thatâ€™s a lot of â€œifs,â€ and we lose everything if any one of them goes the wrong way.

And Carole Cadwalladr reminds us that the illegality and foreign money in the referendum have never been addressed.

Another â€œifâ€: if Johnson could have got the deal through parliament, why did he back down and go for the election? Maybe itâ€™s just be that he expects to get a majority, and thereby make it easier to get the WAB through in a new parliament. But I canâ€™t help thinking that heâ€™s up to something. That he and Dominic Cummings have some plan that will get around parliament somehow.

Hard to see what that could be, but how far would you trust those proven liars and crooks?

items.title: On Pausing Stories
items.content_text:
Almost exactly a year ago I started reading a novel, then put it on hold. This year Iâ€™ve done the same, for different reasons.

I started The Long Way to a Small, Angry Planet by Becky Chambers in October of last year. I quickly put it aside as November approached. I realised that it â€” or at least its start â€” was much too similar to the novel that I planned to start for NaNoWriMo.

I havenâ€™t got back to it yet.

This year it was the new Philip Pullman, The Book of Dust vol 2: The Secret Commonwealth

Now, youâ€™ll recall that I said I might do this after I read the first of the new trilogy. Other things got in the way of that, though.

So I read a chapter or two of the new one, and realised I needed to refresh my memories. Thereâ€™s a whole thing that we learn about at once that I donâ€™t remember. Or at least donâ€™t remember how it happened.

Thereâ€™s also a TV series coming. I was aware it was in development, but not of how soon it was going to be. Turns out itâ€™ll be on in a week or two.

So now Iâ€™m worried that watching it is going to be a bit like the recent Good Omens series was for me; really well done, I appreciated itâ€¦ but I had re-read the book too soon before watching it, meaning it was all just a bit too recent in my memory for maximum enjoyment. But weâ€™ll cross that ice bridge to another world when we come it it. The trailers look great, anyway.

The difference with this yearâ€™s pause will be that, while I will get back to the Chambers eventually, Iâ€™m obviously not in any hurry to do so. Whereas I fully expect to restart The Secret Commonwealth as soon as Iâ€™ve recovered from the ending of The Amber Spyglass. Which Iâ€™ll probably be starting quite soon.

items.title: The Handmaid's Tale by Margaret Atwood (Books 2019, 15)
items.content_text:
Itâ€™s to my shame that I hadnâ€™t read this classic of modern literature before now. And it turns out, now that I have, that itâ€™s really good. Surprise, surprise. I donâ€™t really care for dystopias, as Iâ€™ve said before. Interesting that the book I linked to there had just won the Clarke, and the one weâ€™re discussing was the inaugural winner of that award.

For the first few chapters I was distracted by wondering how this situation, this state, could have come to be. Strangely what I found difficult to cope with was not the restrictions, the rolling back of rights â€” they are horrific, but I could and can easily imagine an America (or, hell, maybe even a Britain) that could enact those laws.

No, what I found hardest to believe in was the dress codes. The way not just the Handmaids, but the marthas (domestic servants), econowives (lower-class, probably infertile women, assigned to lower-class men) and even Wives (the wives of the ruling-class men) all dress in the standard costume of their class.

Somehow I feel â€” or at least felt â€” that it would be harder to get everyone to dress the same way than to obey laws that restrict more important freedoms.

As the chapters went on, those concerns evaporated. The telling of the backstory through Offredâ€™s reminiscences outlines a convincing route from 80s America to Gilead. Though a lot more could be told: it is only an outline. Still, itâ€™s enough.

These days, with actual nazis poisoning our political discourse, and attempts to roll back reproductive rights even in France, it sometimes feels â€” as Atwood no doubt intended â€” that Gilead is not so much a fable as a warning.
Where, and in what direction, am I meant to slide? Because I canâ€™t get past this screen in the iPhone camera app â€œManual.â€

items.title: The End of Newspaper Delivery
items.content_text:
Weâ€™ve been getting The Guardian delivered on Saturdays for several years. Not any other days, because who has time to read paper newspapers except at the weekend? But itâ€™s great to get up and have the paper there to read over breakfast.

Sadly, a couple of weeks back we got a note with our delivery:

Sorry, we are stopping deliveries from the 1st of October.

Not too surprising, I suppose. Itâ€™s hard to imagine that enough people get deliveries to make it worth their time and effort. And itâ€™s not like theyâ€™re going out of business: theyâ€™ll still be selling papers, just not delivering them.

So I suppose weâ€™ll have to go out and buy the paper on Saturday mornings, like itâ€™s the â€” actually, not like itâ€™s the past at all. Iâ€™d bet that there have been newspaper deliveries as long as there have been newspapers.

Still, itâ€™s not like theyâ€™ve stopped everywhere. I expect there are still a few places out there that still deliver. But what next? Will our milkman stop delivering?1

In this golden age of home deliveries, remember that we depend on people being willing and able.

items.title: Jason & Dan
items.content_text:
If you saw my post the other day complaining about typography, you might have been confused. I went to see Jason & The Scorchers last Friday. They were playing in a co-headline tour with the Kentucky Headhunters and Dan Baird & Homemade Sin.

On the night we saw them, the order they took the stage was: Headhunters, Scorchers, Homemade Sin.

That was completely the wrong order, at least for the audience at Londonâ€™s Shepherdâ€™s Bush Empire on that night. The energy and connection of the Scorchers meant that the peak for the whole event came as they finished their set â€” in the middle of the evening.

No doubt you think I just think that because Iâ€™m a fan of the Scorchers, and not particularly of Dan Baird. And there is some truth to that. But I watched the last twenty minutes or so from off to one side â€” OK, I was standing at the bar â€” so I had a good view of the front of the crowd; and it was clear that they werenâ€™t as excited, as into it, as involved, as they had been an hour before.

No matter, it was still a great night, and Iâ€™m sure some people were happy that the running order was that way round. What drove me to post that picture, though, was the distraction that backdrop caused me. I couldnâ€™t really appreciate the music for staring at it.

In case itâ€™s not obvious to you, take a look at the ampersand, and tell me how thereâ€™s any possible way it can make sense in that orientation.

items.title: Tarantino Thoughts
items.content_text:
Quentin Tarantinoâ€™s Once Upon A Time In Hollywood is kind of a love story, kind of a biopic, and kind of a history.

Note that this post contains spoilers. Donâ€™t read on if you havenâ€™t seen it and care about being spoiled.

Or maybe â€œbuddy pic,â€ rather than â€œlove story;â€ but the relationship between the two leads will be analysed for its homoerotic content, no doubt.

How it certainly has been described is â€œa love letter to Hollywood,â€ and thatâ€™s fair enough. What it also is, is a counter-factual, or alternative history. But donâ€™t worry, Iâ€™m not going to claim this one for SF.1

The main characters â€“ fading cowboy actor Rick Dalton, played by Leonardo DiCaprio, and his regular stunt double Cliff Booth, played by Brad Pitt â€“ are invented. But most of the other named characters, and many who are mentioned or appear as extras, are real people. The most significant of these is Sharon Tate, played by Margot Robbie. And itâ€™s her story that makes this film most interesting, and maybe problematic.

Because of course she died tragically, murdered by members of Charles Mansonâ€™s â€œFamilyâ€ cult. And in this version â€” she doesnâ€™t.

If you know the history â€” which of course, many younger people wonâ€™t, which makes for different ways of experiencing the film â€” then you spend half the time expecting the massacre. There are captioned dates, and even though most of us wouldnâ€™t know the date of the murders, there canâ€™t really be any other reason for showing them. And then when it comes, something else happens.

The violence in that scene is gruesome, over the top, ludicrous â€” almost hallucinogenic, making me wonder if the tripping Booth2 is meant to have hallucinated some or all of it. But thereâ€™s no need for there to be so much of it, or for the majority of it to be directed at women. The â€œFamilyâ€ did consist largely of women, I guess, but I canâ€™t help but feeling that Tarantino is revelling in it a little too much.

And on top of all that, as my family agreed after seeing it: thereâ€™s no real need for the whole Sharon Tate thread of the story. It would have made a fine tale if were just about the two actors against the backdrop of late-60s Hollywood. I wonder what the point of it was. Did Tarantino feel he could in some way â€œsaveâ€ Sharon Tate?

  1. Although that might be an interesting exercise. There isnâ€™t really enough after the big change to make it worthwhile, though.Â â†©
  2. Thereâ€™s probably no significance to his having the same surname as the killer in David Lynchâ€™s Blue Velvet. Probably.Â â†©

If youâ€™re familiar with the area and the local slang (which may in fact be national or global slang in places), itâ€™s particularly enjoyable. But the themes are universal, so donâ€™t suppose itâ€™s only for Hackney & Islington folk.

items.title: In Dreams: A Unified Interpretation of Twin Peaks & Other Selected Works of David Lynch, by H Perry Horton (Books 2019, 7)
items.content_text:
This is an incredible piece of work, about an incredible body of work.

I donâ€™t recall how I heard about it. I think I saw a tweet, or something, thought it looked interesting, and instantly bought it because it was only a few quid on Kindle. Itâ€™s a huge book which tries â€” successfully, in my mind â€” to explain how the bulk of David Lynchâ€™s creative works can be considered part of a single story, which Horton refers to as The Dream.

Now obviously Twin Peaks, Twin Peaks: Fire Walk With Me, and Twin Peaks: The Return are all part of the same story. As are the various spinoff books: Jennifer Lynchâ€™s The Secret Diary of Laura Palmer, and Scott Frostâ€™s The Autobiography of FBI Special Agent Dale Cooper: My Life, My Tapes, from back around the time of the original broadcast; and Mark Frostâ€™s more recent The Secret History of Twin Peaks and Twin Peaks: The Final Dossier, which Iâ€™ve written about here.

But Horton argues that the whole story gets kicked off in Eraserhead, and that Blue Velvet, Lost Highway, Mulholland Dr and Inland Empire are side stories related to the main branch. The overall story being about an eternal being, The Dreamer, who dreams reality into existence, and also creates another being, known as Jowday, or Judy, who becomes his adversary. BOB, the possessing spirit of the original Twin Peaks, is a creation of this entity, and the Black and White Lodges are the vanguards in the battle between the two beings.

Sure, on one level itâ€™s just good vs evil, heaven & hell â€” â€œjust,â€ I say, as if that wasnâ€™t enough. But the sheer scope of it is astonishing. The eighteen hours of The Return has been hailed as an incredible masterpiece of visual storytelling. But when you include all that Iâ€™ve listed above, and three of Lynchâ€™s paintings to boot â€” it must be one of the greatest â€” in terms of size, at least â€” creative works by a single visionary. True, itâ€™s far from being by a single creator, but the vision behind it is solely or primarily Lynchâ€™s, or that of Lynch and Mark Frost.

And even if the connections to the other films are just in Hortonâ€™s head (and, to be fair, those of others whose work he acknowledges): the obviously-connected stuff is still amazing, and the current work, Hortonâ€™s book that Iâ€™m writing about, is something a of a creative triumph itself.

One that is slightly marred by its self-published nature and obvious lack of an editor â€” there are a lot of typos â€” but a hugely impressive one nonetheless.

Though obviously itâ€™s only for the very serious Twin Peaks fan.
Sometimes you just put on Combat Rock, and you are reminded of how awesome it is.

items.title: Rational? Twitter, Micro.blog and Social Engagement
items.content_text:
I had vaguely seen references to â€œratios,â€ and was aware it was something to do with engagement on Twitter and elsewhere. But I hadnâ€™t understood what exactly people meant by it. Then last night I saw a tweet in which someone said, â€œI accept Iâ€™ve been ratiod.â€ (Should the verb form rather be â€œratioedâ€? Hard to say. Neither looks quite right.)

A search for understanding led me to this article on Know Your Meme. It tells us:

The Ratio refers to an unofficial Twitter law which states that if the amount of replies to a tweet greatly outnumbers the amount of retweets and likes, then the tweet is bad

and goes into some detail about the origin of the term.

It makes me sad to read that. Imagine an interaction system where, if people reply to something you say, thatâ€™s bad. Well, it seems we donâ€™t have to imagine it: we can see it right here on the â€œsocialâ€ web.

I like to get replies on Twitter or elsewhere. A reply means, to me, that someone has read what Iâ€™ve written, thought about it, and found it worth responding to. Iâ€™m aware that I speak from a position of some privilege, in that Iâ€™m not in a group that is likely to experience the mass abuse that many do. But something has broken down in our systems of interaction if getting replies mean what you said â€œis bad.â€

Iâ€™m far from the first to have made that observation, of course.

But consider Micro.blog, the still-young social network based on blogs that Iâ€™ve written abut before. Micro.blog has replies, but it doesnâ€™t even have the concept of likes or retweets/reblogs. If you read a post and want to say something about it â€” even just that you like it â€” you have to reply. With words, in human language.

Itâ€™s a much friendlier place than Twitter.

This conversation from the last day or two gives a good flavour of the kind of thing you can expect.

If you clicked through that link youâ€™ll have seen that it appears to be â€” and is â€” on the blog of the user who made the original post. The responses appear as blog comments. But while every Micro.blog user has a blog, you donâ€™t have to interact with it as a blog if you donâ€™t want to. You can do it all through the Micro.blog app or one of the third-party clients, or just the Micro.blog website, where you can see the same conversation.

Similarly, you can see all my posts here, as well as at their natural home.

Itâ€™s well worth a try if youâ€™re looking for a less toxic social-media environment.

You should be watching Russel T Daviesâ€™s Years and Years. This thread nails it:

Itâ€™s scary because life is scary sometimes. People are brilliant, maddening, contradictory, and full of love.

and:

Iâ€™m dying to find out what happened, but scared to watch at the same time.

I donâ€™t know when I last sat down to watch a Scotland-England football match. Indeed, I donâ€™t know when there last was a Scotland-England match. It used to be every year with the Home Internationals, but that was long ago. Quite looking forward to this, though.

So itâ€™s quite clear: UKIP/Brexit Party on much the same as five years ago. Many switching from Tories and Labour to Lib Dems and Greens. Change UK have, at best, split the remain vote.

Not the big swing some are making out. #EuropeElects

Based on the stats they just put up on the BBC, the pro- and anti-Brexit groupings have 35% of the vote each. Thatâ€™s not counting Labour or the Tories, of course, because their votes donâ€™t give a clear picture. #EuropeElects
If the Brexit Party are â€œup 3â€³ seats, and UKIP down 3 seats: thatâ€™s no change, in reality. #EuropeElects

items.title: Two Wheels Good
items.content_text:
Back when the internet was young â€” or at least the commercial, available-at-home internet â€” I sent an email with the subject line, â€œBicycle on the Superhighwayâ€. It was about me having a publicly-accessible email address for the first time since uni (as opposed to one that was only usable within the company where I worked at the time).

This was back when people â€” inspired, if I recall correctly, by Al Gore â€” were calling the net the â€œInformation Superhighway.â€

This post is not about all that, though; this is about literal cycling on a literal superhighway: specifically Londonâ€™s â€œCycle Superhighways.â€

Since the building where I now work has showers, I decided it was time to get back on the bike. And since itâ€™s in Westminster, it turns out thereâ€™s a really easy route, that uses CS6 and CS3: down Farringdon Road and west along Embankment, by the river.

These are fantastic cycling facilities, especially the Embankment one. Properly separated from the motor traffic, plenty of room to move and overtake, great sequencing of traffic lights so you hardly have to stop. Itâ€™s hard to fault it. Especially compared to nearly every other pathetic painted cycle lane in the city.

It gets a bit hairy where it all ends, in Parliament Square: the traffic there is unfeasibly heavy. Who drives near parliament?

If thereâ€™s a downside to it all, itâ€™s this: I suspect that the motorised traffic is busier and faster, exactly because itâ€™s not tempered by having bikes in the mix. I canâ€™t be sure â€” Iâ€™ve never used Embankment before, and itâ€™s years since I used to cycle regularly on Farringdon Road â€” but it feels to me that thereâ€™s a crazy amount of traffic and that itâ€™s going faster than ever.

The latter canâ€™t really be true â€” there are still speed limits, and they either wonâ€™t have changed or might have dropped to 20 mph in sections. But I still get this sense that, freed from interacting with the fragile two-wheeled minority, the armoured legions behave more like theyâ€™re on a motorway.

Whether thatâ€™s the case or not, the number of people cycling â€” especially in the recent bright spring weather â€” is huge. The only time Iâ€™ve seen more cyclists together was when I did the London to Brighton ride many years ago.

And also in the mix now are electric scooters and electric skateboards, which makes it all the more interesting. Thereâ€™s even the odd cycle rickshaw.

Itâ€™ll be interesting to see how the volume changes with the seasons, but you canâ€™t beat it for a way to commute: itâ€™s faster than the tube, it saves you money, and you get some exercise. I recommend it for anyone whoâ€™s able.

items.title: Words Matter. Phrasing Matters
items.content_text:
On the BBC Radio 3 news this morning:

Instead of making it sound like a burden is being placed upon us, how about saying something like:

As part of the European Unionâ€™s democratic processes, Britain, like all member states, enjoys the right to hold elections for members of the European Parliament.

How you express things affects how people think about them.

If you are one of the 3.5 million EU nationals still living here in the UK
â€¦

items.title: Partners
items.content_text:
We went to Parliament Square this morning for the passing into law of Equal Civil Partnerships (the Civil Partnerships, Marriages and Deaths (Registrations etc) bill â€” or now, act â€” to give it its full name).

It has taken a long time, but different-sex couples can now have a civil partnership if they want to. Or will be able to, later this year or early next, once all the paperwork has been processed.

Itâ€™s not the biggest issue in the world â€” it wasnâ€™t even the most important thing happening in Parliament Square this morning (those kids were noisy, and rightly so) â€” but it means a lot to us. Those of us who have problems with traditional marriage. Which just means that it isnâ€™t right for us; itâ€™s up to everyone else whatâ€™s right for them.

Rebecca Steinfeld and Charles Keidan, who took the case to the court, and ultimately the Supreme Court, were there, as was Tim Loughton, the Liberal Democrat MP whose private members bill it was. The government supported it, which is why it was able to get through; but of course they had to do something once the Supreme Court had told them that the existing situation was unlawful.

The stupid thing is that all the time and money and stress could have been saved if civil partnerships had included mixed-sex couples in the first place. I was sure Iâ€™d had this thought back when they were introduced for same-sex couples. I thought I had written about it here. Not much, it turns out. There was a post expressing disappointment with a setback at the Supreme Court before the final decision.

But there was this post about Tony Blairâ€™s legacy, where I said in an aside, â€œthough why not for het couples?â€

I took a few pictures. Did you know thereâ€™s a statue of Abraham Lincoln in Parliament Square? I didnâ€™t. Seems rather strange, but why not, I suppose.

After a week of Brexit insanity and a on a day of horror in New Zealand, itâ€™s good to have some positive news.

items.title: The Beats: a Very Short Introduction (Books 2019, 4)

Since I announced back in October that Iâ€™m writing a novel called Delta Blues: Beat Poet of the Spaceways, I thought I should learn a bit more about the Beats. Not that my character is necessarily going to be very like the actual Beats, and maybe her poetry wonâ€™t be like theirs either, but you need to know about what youâ€™re using for inspiration, right?

Books in the â€œVery Short Introductionâ€ series do exactly what their shared subtitle suggests, and this is no exception. You get a brief prehistory and history of the movement, then a look at the major novelists, another at the major poets, and then a piece on their influence.

In common with the last two books I read, The Clash get a mention, because Allen Ginsberg worked with them, adding spoken-word part to â€œGhetto Defendant,â€ on the Combat Rock album.

I know more about the Beats now than when I started, and thatâ€™s exactly what I wanted out of this book.

I hadnâ€™t even seen this story about Morrissey and his politics and collaborators when I made my last post. But Iâ€™m baffled by this quote:

Representatives for Lydia Night of California band the Regrettes offered no comment, but the 18-year-old told punk magazine Kerrang!: â€œIâ€™ve grown up loving the Smiths â€“ my catâ€™s name is Morrissey!â€

Emphasis mine. When I were a lad â€” and, indeed, when it was launched â€” Kerrang! was a heavy metal magazine. A flagship of one of the enemy camps in the Punk Wars. Has it really changed, or is The Guardian just misinformed?

Or maybe the lines are more blurred than ever before, so it doesnâ€™t really matter.

â€œâ€™80s Indie Essentials,â€ from Apple Music. Really good, and has several things I didnâ€™t know, as well as much I did. Perhaps too much Smiths, especially with Morrisseyâ€™s fall from grace, but they did make some good records.

items.title: England's Dreaming: Sex Pistols and Punk Rock, by Jon Savage (Books 2019, 3)
items.content_text:
I didnâ€™t start reading this just because I read a book about The Clash recently. In fact I started it sometime last year. But reading the Clash book did make me want to get back to this, and refresh my memories of the early days of punk.

Reading a history of a time you lived through is interesting. Not that I was involved in the events, but I was distantly aware of at least some of them. In the years the book covers I was between 12 and 15. Or maybe just 14, as it only gets as far as early 79. Itâ€™s a short period of time, looking back, and they â€” the Pistols, and most of the other bands too â€” were incredibly young. They were just 20 and 21 when they signed their first deal. And their second. And their third.

At times Savage appears to think that punk was over when the pistols split, if not before. And generally to have quite negative thoughts about it as it developed Though he undercuts that contempt later, in the appendices and in the notes scattered through the huge discography at the end. He acknowledges the influence of punk, though considers it just to be one of a range of genres or forms that influences popular music. Which is fair enough, though there are still, even today, bands that consider themselves to be punk. Whether thatâ€™s a good thing or not, I donâ€™t know.

Something that came out of it that surprised me â€” though doesnâ€™t, now that I know the facts â€” is that you can no longer get the film of The Great Rock â€˜nâ€™ Roll Swindle in any form (though you can still get the soundtrack album). Thatâ€™s because it was McLarenâ€™s project, it sets him up as hero, and makes Lydon the almost-unseen villain. Lydon hated McLaren by the end, and eventually won control of the Sex Pistols name and assets in a series of court cases. Presumably he controls whether it will ever be released.

I find this mildly annoying, because I saw it couple of times when I was a student, and enjoyed it, and wouldnâ€™t mind seeing it again. Second-hand DVD copies are available, but theyâ€™re mostly pricey and/or being shipped from the States.

I suppose the more recent, documentary film, The Filth and the Fury, might be worth seeing. I see that, like The Swindle, it is directed by Julien Temple. Clearly Lydon didnâ€™t mind his work on McLarenâ€™s film.

What doesnâ€™t come through very much is any sense of Jon Savage himself. What was he doing, and how did he get involved in all this? I gather he wrote a fanzine, Londonâ€™s Outrage, and he became a journalist writing for Sounds, according to his Wikipedia entry. While he has done extensive research, and interviewed many of the participants, some of the story clearly comes from his being there at the time.

But the only real sense of that we get is that, towards the last third or so of the book, a series of dated, italicised entries appear. They clearly are â€” or are meant to be â€” diary entries from the time. Or notes for articles he wrote at the time, perhaps, giving us something of a first-person view of some to the gigs and so on. I would have liked to see more made of these, or more generally about his experience and from his point of view. A book about punk ought to be a bit more gonzo, I think.

But on the whole itâ€™s a great read.

items.title: Unhelpful Thoughts On Brexit
items.content_text:
You could spend a lot of time wondering what makes Theresa May tick.

She says she supported remain and voted to stay in the European Union. So her increasing fervour for Brexit has been one of the most confusing factors in British politics over the last two and a half years.

Taking over the Tory leadership after David Cameron resigned was always going to be a poisoned chalice. No-one would have had a good time in that position, except maybe a genuine hard quitter like Jacob Rees-Mogg. Thatâ€™s probably why Gove and Johnson pulled out.

If she truly believed that staying in was best, though, she would not have rushed into triggering Article 50 (nor would she have gone to court to fight for her wish to do so by diktat; luckily National Hero Gina Miller had the nationâ€™s back on that one).

If she had used more care, collaboration, and consideration, she might have had an easier time when Article 50 finally was triggered and the negotiations started. In fact if she had been more thoughtful in the first place she might even have said something like, â€œThe vote was close; the country is clearly divided. We will discuss the possible ways forward in parliament and with the rest of the EU, and come back to you, the people, for confirmation when we better understand what Brexit means.â€ 1

But no: â€œBrexit means Brexitâ€: she knew up front what it meant, and never deviated. Even if the majority of the country had no idea what it would mean.

She then proceeded as follows:

  • ignore any idea of cross-party talks and so involving parliament (the UKâ€™s sovereign body) in the negotiations;
  • trigger Article 50 as soon as she could;
  • negotiate with the EU27 almost in secret;
  • have inflexible â€œred linesâ€ to appease the hard quitters, leaving herself no room for compromise in the negotiations.

Itâ€™s a truism, even a cliche, to say that she puts the Tory party before the country. But the only way I can explain such a dramatic change of heart is that her love for the Tory party overruled her knowledge that being in the EU was, is, and will be the best situation for the UK. And that she somehow convinced herself that she could heal her fatally-divided party.

In fact, the very thing that Cameron was trying to do by calling he referendum in the first place.

â€œTory euroscepticsâ€ used to be a common enough phrase, but it denoted a tiny fringe of the party: a few loons like John Redwood. But in trying to appease them, two Tory leaders and prime ministers have turned them mainstream and brought us to where we are today, on the brink of leaving the EU without any kind of agreement for our future relationship.

And their party is as divided as ever.

  1. Thatâ€™s fanciful, of course. But itâ€™s what a sane, thoughtful person, who cared about what might happen to the country would have done.Â â†©

items.title: We Are The Clash by Mark Andersen and Ralph Heibutzki (Books 2019, 2)
items.content_text:
We Are The Clash with the Cut the Crap CD

This is the book that I mentioned before Christmas. The subtitle is â€œReagan, Thatcher, and the Last Stand of A Band That Mattered,â€1 which captures well its structure. It interleaves the politics of what was happening on both sides of the Atlantic â€” the minersâ€™ strike, Reaganâ€™s nuclear brinksmanship, the Iran/Contra scandal â€” with what was happening with the most political of the original punk bands.

Itâ€™s interesting to read a history of a time you lived through and were, however tangentially, involved in. Andersen and Heibutzki more than do justice to their material. The research they must have done is impressive. I know personally that Andersen came to the UK on a research trip, but aside from that they have interviewed the three non-original members of The Clash, Kosmo Vinyl, and various other people who were involved or just had something useful to say.

And they must have spent a lot of time listening to concert tapes and studying set lists â€” which doesnâ€™t sound like a chore to me, itâ€™s fair to say.

I learned two major things: first, Iâ€™d forgotten how good Cut the Crap is. I havenâ€™t listened to it in ages, and when I went to do so on Apple Music, I found it isnâ€™t there. Nor is it on Spotify. I have it on vinyl, but I donâ€™t currently have access to a record player.

Luckily Amazon and CDs both still exist, so I put some more money the way ofâ€¦ Bernie Rhodes, as it turns out.

Thatâ€™s the other big thing I found out: how â€” difficult, letâ€™s say â€” Rhodes was. Not least since he signed the band â€” well, Joe and Paul: the others were effectively employees â€” into a contract that gave him, Rhodes, control over the album, as well as the name â€œThe Clash.â€

But worse was the way he treated the new members while they were with the band. Constantly haranguing them, telling them they werenâ€™t up to scratch, shouting at themâ€¦ itâ€™s a wonder they stayed. It sounds like an abusive environment.

Joe could and should have stopped it, but it seems like he was still to some extent in Rhodesâ€™s thrall â€” Bernie did bring the band together, after all â€” and possible suffering from depression. Certainly he was drinking heavily, and during that time his dad died and his mum got ill, and he became a father himself. It was a difficult time for him.

I have more to say about the album, but I think thatâ€™s for a separate post. For now, this is a great rock book about a little-discussed time in the history of my favourite band.

  1. Good to see the proper use of the Oxford comma there.Â â†©

items.title: Flights by Olga Tokarczuk (Books 2019, 1)
items.content_html:
Iâ€™m pleased to have finished the first book of the year â€” and the first of my Christmas books â€” already. Itâ€™s a book about travel, and the human body, and some people and things that happen to them. Is it a novel? It consists of a series of short sections, and a few longer ones. I canâ€™t really call them chapters: some are no more than a paragraph, even a sentence. It does have characters, though: notably the narrator, who is the voice of most of the shorter sections. She appears to be someone who spends most of her life travelling around the world without necessarily any destination or purpose in mind.

That doesnâ€™t make it sound as compelling as it is. There are connections between at least some of the stories, which make me think there must be more connections that I missed. A lot of it regards the preservation of dead bodies, from early embalming techniques to the â€œBody Worldsâ€ plastination of Gunther von Hagens.

In the end it doesnâ€™t quite form a unified whole, so in that sense Iâ€™m not sure we can really call it a novel. But itâ€™s strangely compelling, and I thoroughly enjoyed it.

This post on someone whoâ€™s trying to bring Starbucks-style coffee shops to Italy is kind of annoying. Not least for the closing quote:

â€œItâ€™s not that Italian coffee has always been bad,â€ Campeotto said. â€œThey have been geniuses. The god of coffee is the Italian espresso. The problem is, they have been stuck there. They stopped.â€

If they had already achieved the â€œgod of coffeeâ€ (which I happen to agree with), then why would they do anything other than stop? If youâ€™ve already achieved perfection you have no need to improve. Just make sure you maintain that level.

I spent twelve months of 1989-90 in Turin. A cappuccino was 1200 lire, or about 60p (around 45-50 US cents, probably). And it was delicious. The best coffee I had, or have, ever tasted.

The growth of Starbucks and the other chains came after that, and Iâ€™ve been looking for coffee as good ever since. Iâ€™ve never found it. The closest I ever found in London was Costa in its early days. It has slipped down to the level of Starbucks and CaffÃ¨ Nero, though.

Which is not to say that any of those are truly bad: not, at least, compared to what was available before they came on the scene.

But nothing matches my memory of Torinese cappuccino.

items.title: Bing Me the Head of the Marketing Team

I keep seeing these posters around town saying, â€œIâ€™m a binger.â€ And I think, â€œWhatâ€™s that, is it someone who uses Microsoftâ€™s search engine? One who uses Bing?â€ Itâ€™s for a broadband provider â€” TalkTalk, I think â€” so it sounds plausibleâ€¦ just.

Then I realise itâ€™s â€œone who binges.â€ Thereâ€™s no obvious way in written English to specify which of the two pronunciations you mean. Youâ€™d have to write â€œbinge-erâ€ or something. Not ideal.

Youâ€™d have thought someone in the marketing team would have spotted the potential confusion and suggested taking a different tack. But then again, maybe they did, and they thought that the momentary confusion would draw peopleâ€™s attention and make them notice the poster.

Which clearly worked.

items.title: Who's Who?
items.content_text:
Right, letâ€™s get 2019 off to a start by talking about my favourite TV programme. I havenâ€™t said anything about the recent season of Doctor Who here since my appreciative post at the end of the first episode. Not for any reason other than not getting round to it.

I absolutely love this iteration of the series. Jodie Whittaker is fantastic as The Doctor, and the supporting cast is brilliant as well. I like the crowded Tardis feel. It does have the limitation that some of the characters donâ€™t get as much time or as many lines as others. Thatâ€™s been notably true of Yaz â€” except in the â€œDemons of the Punjabâ€ episode, of course.

But thereâ€™s plenty of time for her to be developed further, assuming theyâ€™re all sticking around. And the focus being more on Ryan and Graham was entirely correct, since if there was an overarching theme to the season, it was grief.

Itâ€™s not perfect. There have been several occasions when Iâ€™ve thought that the writing team donâ€™t really understand what a galaxy is, or the scale of it. Lines like â€œhalf the people in the galaxy are unemployed,â€ or â€œtheyâ€™ve crossed four galaxies to get here,â€ just donâ€™t really make a lot of sense. And there have been several episodes where things maybe werenâ€™t as tidily resolved as weâ€™re used to.

Tonightâ€™s New Year special episode, â€œResolution,â€ was a classic example of the kind of story where the ideas are good, but the whole thing could have been improved if theyâ€™d taken the time to come up with slightly better ways to make things happen. Some way of defeating the enemy that didnâ€™t involve the microwave oven, for example. And the whole vacuum/supernova bit at the end was kind of farcical.

But no matter. This season was all about the character dynamics, and those were great. Itâ€™s a strong start for Chris Chibnall as showrunner, and an incredibly strong start for Jodie Whittaker.
Happy New Year, everyone. It could be a rough one, so look out for each other.

items.title: Creative Selection by Ken Kocienda (Books 2018, 31)
items.content_text:
Hey, I made it to 31, by reading the last chapter of this on the last day of the year.

This book, subtitled â€œInside Appleâ€™s Design Process During the Golden Age of Steve Jobs,â€ is written by the software engineer who worked on the original version of the iPhoneâ€™s software keyboard. Itâ€™s an interesting view into how things were for someone working at Apple at the time.

Thatâ€™s not something we often get, with the companyâ€™s noted dedication to secrecy, so itâ€™s good for that. But while I did get a sense of what it was like, I feel that thereâ€™s an awful lot more he could tell, especially about the people. We do get a sense of some of them, but not much insight. And especially not about he author himself. We learn next to nothing about him outside of his work.

Maybe thatâ€™s the way you have to be when you work at somewhere as high-pressure as Apple. Worth a read if youâ€™re interested in Apple and their products.

items.title: Stormwatch by Warren Ellis, Tom Raney and Bryan Hitch (Books 2018, 30)
items.content_text:
I donâ€™t always include all comic-type things here. No particular reason why, except maybe that they sometimes feel too short and not substantial enough. I probably wouldnâ€™t have included this, except that it conveniently gets my total for the year to thirty.

Itâ€™s a post-Watchmen story of superheroes handled in a vaguely realist fashion. At least in the sense that thereâ€™s some consideration of politics. Stormwatch is a UN body, an emergency response team. It has its base in a satellite, and superhuman beings who are tasked with dealing with incursions from other worlds, or other, nefarious, super-powered beings. The US is usually antagonistic to it, because of its UN status.

Itâ€™s not bad, but honestly not much to write home about.

items.title: The Drifters by James A Michener (Books 2018, 29)
items.content_text:
I think Iâ€™ve read this more times than any other book except Illuminatus!, and maybe The Lord of the Rings. Which may be only three or four times. A friend got into Michener when we were teenagers. None of his books much interested me, until I looked at this.

Itâ€™s a tale of hippies and others in 1969. Six young people from various countries meet each other in Torremolinos, and drift around the Iberian Peninsula and parts of Africa. The narrator, seemingly detached third-person at first, turns out to be an older man who knows some of the young people, and arranges business trips so that he can hang out with them from time to time.

Itâ€™s about what was going on in the world â€” Vietnam, the Arab/Israeli conflict, drugs, music â€” and about the characters. They arenâ€™t that well developed â€” indeed, he largely abandons character development after the first six chapters where he introduces each one â€” but those introductions are enough to see us through.

Actually, thinking about it now, I wish he had written more about some of them. A sequel would have been in order.

Itâ€™s partly, I suspect, Michenerâ€™s own struggle to come to terms with the way society is changing â€” he was born in 1907, so heâ€™d have been 62 at the time this is set. It was published in 71, so maybe a tad older when he wrote it. The narrator, George Fairbanks, is younger than that, I think â€” probably in his fifties, maybe even forties, but people seemed to become old at a younger age back then.

Well worth a read.

items.title: Na? No
items.content_text:
I expect youâ€™re all wondering what happened with my NaNoWriMo attempt this year. Sadly, after last yearâ€™s success, this year I failed.

As youâ€™ll have seen if you clicked through to look at my stats, I averaged 595 words per day, for a total of 17,800. Itâ€™s not nothing, and itâ€™s still a decent start on the new novel, but itâ€™s nothing like last year.

Why did I fail? A better question is, why was I successful last year? This yearâ€™s result is comparable to other years when Iâ€™ve tried it. Last yearâ€™s success looks like the aberration.

The big difference between last year and any other was my commute. Iâ€™ve tended always to have a commute of about an hour â€” except when I worked at the bank in the City, when it was shorter. Last year I was working in Croydon, which took me an hour and a half or more to get to. The one good point was that, picking up the Overground from Dalston Junction, I nearly always got a seat within a few stops. And on the way back had one from the start (coming from West Croydon, which is the start of the line).

So I was able to get forty or fifty minutes of concentrated writing time in each direction. Add to that the fact that the office I was in was really horrible, so I didnâ€™t want to spend my lunch hours in it. I mostly went out and wrote in cafes or at Boxpark Croydon. The one thing I miss about that job is the the places to eat, especially a little pizza place in Boxpark.

Whereas now, working at Imperial, Iâ€™m back to a one-hour commute, with much less guarantee of a seat. And I really like both job and office, so Iâ€™m quite happy to go back there after Iâ€™ve got my lunch.

One other point is that last year I had worked out how I was going to end the novel I had been working on for years, so I was running downhill towards that end. This year, starting a brand-new one â€” even though Iâ€™ve got a plan, it feels much more uphill.

Still, we press on, writers against procrastination, borne forward ceaselessly into the future.
All the congratulations to NASA for another successful landing on Mars. Good to know humanity can still do great things.
Did I hear right on https://www.nasa.gov/nasalive? The principal scientist for Mars Insight is Bruce Banner? Hope he stays clear of gamma rays. And doesnâ€™t get angry.
