items.title: Everything Rhymes
items.content_text:
Doctor Who is back! And at Easter, which still feels like the right time of the year.

Now, as youâ€™ll know, I thought last season was the best season of New Who. I may have been being a tad hyperbolic thereâ€¦ but not entirely.

And now weâ€™ve got â€œThe Pilot,â€ the first episode of the new season. Introducing Pearl Mackie as Bill Potts. Among other things, Iâ€™ve got to say that this would be a great jumping-on point; a fine episode for someone new to the series to start.

The story was good, not great; there were unnecessary Daleks, but if that means theyâ€™re going to otherwise be given a rest for this season, I wonâ€™t complain; and weâ€™ve got the mysterious vault that The Doctor and Nardole are investigating. I suspect it might be most of the season before we find out whatâ€™s going on with that.

Nice references to the past with the pictures of River and Susan; and the people who were fighting the Daleks were Movellans, apparently. I learned this on Jason Snellâ€™s Doctor Who Flashcast podcast. I knew I recognised them, so I thought they must be Thals, and that we were right back at the start of it all. Itâ€™s a very long time since I saw either.

So, The Doctor has been lecturing at Bristol University for maybe fifty years? Intriguing. And the mini-trailer that we got as well as the usual â€œNext timeâ€¦â€ is even more so. Both Missy and John Simm (presumably as The Master). The start of The Doctorâ€™s regeneration sequence. We know heâ€™s going to regenerate, but not, presumably till the last episode.

Though on that point, Capaldi said on The Graham Norton Show that he had already filmed his part of the regeneration scene, and the only thing they still had to film was the Christmas special. Not surprisingly he wouldnâ€™t give an explanation of that paradox.

I have a theory, or suggestion for how things might develop. They wonâ€™t do this, and they shouldnâ€™t; but bear with me.

In a reversal of the now-common trope of The Doctorâ€™s companion falling for him, The Doctor falls for Bill. She, of course, is not interested. So The Doctor regenerates into a female form.

That would be to put Billâ€™s sexuality too much to the fore, and of course be wildly unlike The Doctor. But it amused me to consider for a few minutes.

items.title: So, Entitled
items.content_text:
In a recent article in the Guardian, this appeared:

It is no oneâ€™s â€œdestinyâ€ to be a published author. That implies a path laid out for us, an unshakeable future that is planned and unchangeable. And it is entitled.

That is a perfectly normal use of the modern sense of the word â€œentitled,â€ and it still slightly bothers me, as it has lo! these several years.

Because what it really means is that the person isnâ€™t actually entitled to the thing in question. The older sense of â€œentitleâ€ is to have the right to something â€” literally to have the title.

The modern meaning â€” the â€œHeâ€™s so entitledâ€ formulation â€” really means â€œHeâ€™s behaving as if he were entitled toâ€¦â€

Dictionary.com gives the definition of entitle as:

to give (a person or thing) a title, right, or claim to something; furnish with grounds for laying claim

Merriam-Webster is similar;

1: to give a title to : designate
2: to furnish with proper grounds for seeking or claiming something this ticket entitles the bearer to free admission

And neither has the modern meaning at all.

But Iâ€™m slightly horrified to find that the built-in dictionary in MacOS only has the modern meaning:

adjective
believing oneself to be inherently deserving of privileges or special treatment: kids who feel so entitled and think the world will revolve around them

Itâ€™s interesting, though, that its definition of entitle is similar to the two web-based ones. And Cambridge has both. It seems the difference is whether you use the verb or the adjective. The latter is the only one with the modern meaning.

Language changes, and thatâ€™s fine. But I wish that people who use it in the modern fashion understood what it is theyâ€™re saying, and what it can sound like theyâ€™re saying. I suspect they mostly donâ€™t.

Theyâ€™re behaving like theyâ€™re entitled to make words mean whatever they want.

items.title: BSFA Awards 2016 by Various (Books 2017, 3)
items.content_text:
Interrupting my Alan Moore reading to check on the short-fiction nominees for the BSFA Awards, reprinted as ever in an A4 booklet.

Good stuff, of course, but maybe not as good as last year (though I realised that I hadnâ€™t read all of last yearâ€™s). Letâ€™s go through them one by one.

Warning: spoilers follow.

â€œThe End of Hope Street,â€ by Malcolm Devlin

This is a strange story, set in the present day, about houses becoming â€œunliveable.â€ This phenomenon is completely unexplained, but it is disastrous, and can even be fatal. And it accepted fatalistically by the large, and largely undifferentiated, cast of characters.

â€œLiberty Bird,â€ by Jayne Fenn

The favoured son of a noble clan races the family yacht. In spaaaaaace. But he has a shameful secret that should be neither in highly advanced future society. On the other hand, a highly advanced future society shouldnâ€™t have a nobility. I guess societies can go back as well as forward.

â€œTaking Flight,â€ by Una McCormack

Another rich person mooches around with no real aim in life, this time in a society that has genetically engineered slaves.

â€œPresence,â€ by Helen Oyeyemi

This is the most disjointed, disconnected of the stories. A heterosexual married couple avoid communicating with each other because sheâ€™s convinced heâ€™s about to leave her. Until they do, and it turns out instead that he wants to postpone their holiday so they can try out some sort of therapy for grieving people that he has developed. They do, and things get strange. Thereâ€™s potential here, but all the initial setup about them not communicating is just ignored after they get to the point, so it could have mostly been left out. It really feels like it wants to be two or more different stories.

â€œThe Apologists,â€ by Tade Thompson

A super-advanced alien race have accidentally killed all by five people of the human race. The five are put to work helping the aliens reconstruct a simulacrum of Earth, while a daily apology is blasted at them out of a sound system (hence the title). They seem surprisingly untraumatised by this situation.

â€œThe Arrival of Missivesâ€ (Extract), by Aliya Whiteley

Not sure why this is an extract. Probably the original work is too long to fit in the booklet. A during the First World War a sixteen-year-old girl is in love with her teacher. She decides she has to let him know. The extract ends just when something out of the ordinary is revealed.

Thoughts and Conclusions

Well, I havenâ€™t made them sound very good, have I? I did actually enjoy reading them all, but reduced to capsule summaries, they arenâ€™t going to win any awards. Oh, waitâ€¦

Iâ€™ve no idea which one Iâ€™ll vote for.

items.title: Margaret Atwood's Uncanny Ancestor
items.content_text:
This is a horrific quote from The New Yorkerâ€˜s interview with Margaret Atwood:

Mary Webster, whose neighbors, in the Puritan town of Hadley, Massachusetts, had accused her of witchcraft. â€˜The townspeople didnâ€™t like her, so they strung her up,â€™ Atwood said recently. â€˜But it was before the age of drop hanging, and she didnâ€™t die. She dangled there all night, and in the morning, when they came to cut the body down, she was still alive.â€™ Webster became known as Half-Hanged Mary.

But I canâ€™t help thinking, if thereâ€™s anything to the story, wouldnâ€™t they have taken her survival as further evidence of her witchy nature, and made sure they killed her next time? As it is, it sounds like she lived on.

items.title: You Choose
items.content_html:
Funny where thoughts of current affairs take you.

All the fawning (and, to be fair, condemnatory and neutral) coverage of Trumpâ€™s bombardment of a Syrian air base in response to Assadâ€™s gas attack have stated the quantity and type of munition that was used: â€œ59 Tomahawk Cruise missiles.â€

Those of us who lived under the shadow of the mushroom cloud in the 80s will remember that missile. It was the one stationed at Greenham Common, which of course was the subject of much protest, mainly from the Womenâ€™s Peace Camp.

The Greenham camp was primarily part of the anti-nuclear movement, as the missiles stationed there carried nuclear warheads. Obviously the ones the US launched a couple of nights ago didnâ€™t, but what the whole thing did was remind me of a song from that time: â€œTomahawk Cruise,â€ by TV Smithâ€˜s Explorers.

I recall hearing that song in my Dadâ€™s car1 back when it came out. Itâ€™s possible that I only heard it that one time, but it has stuck in my mind all these years, just waiting to be shaken loose.

On listening to it on Apple Music Iâ€™m pleased to find the chorus is almost exactly as I remembered. The rest of the lyrics are more oblique than Iâ€™d have expected. It was an anti-nuclear song, but less obviously than Iâ€™d have thought.

Itâ€™s very 80s, as you might expect (it was released in 1980), but there is, of course, nothing wrong with that. Inevitably itâ€™s to be found on YouTube and Spotify.

Not sure whether this counts as nostalgia, in terms of my post the other day, but I donâ€™t really care. What definitely isnâ€™t, though, is the album Iâ€™m listening to as I type: The Chiswick Story by Various Artists2 (most of whom I havenâ€™t heard) is a potted history of the label. Lots of good stuff on there.

  1. Bit weird, as he never listened to Radio 1, and thereâ€™s no way it wouldâ€™ve been on Radio 2. I guess maybe I was waiting in the car while my parents shopped. ↩︎

  2. It was suggested because thatâ€™s the label â€œTomahawk Cruiseâ€ was on. ↩︎

items.title: Swim, Test, Shop, Film, Sleep
items.content_text:
Yesterday I kind of wilfully skipped a day. At some point in the evening I realised I wasnâ€™t going to write a post, so I just said, â€œFine: thatâ€™s allowed.â€

Today I started by going for a swim. After my new regime of exercise last summer, I got out of the habit once I started a new contract. So it was good to get back to it. (Which is not to say I havenâ€™t swum or gone to the gym in all that time, but itâ€™s been a few weeks at the moment.)

After that I took a HackerRank test for a new job opportunity. Itâ€™s a site that does programming tests. This one was, I suspect, a disaster. I hate doing that kind of thing: youâ€™ve got a timer running, and the problem youâ€™re trying to solve is unlike anything youâ€™d have to do professionallyâ€¦ Anyway, suffice to say, it didnâ€™t go terribly well.

This evening was all about falling asleep in front of the telly. We tried to watch 20,000 Days On Earth, the film about Nick Cave from a few years back. I got it a few Christmases or birthdays ago, but hadnâ€™t got round to watching it till now. I enjoyed what I saw of it, but there was definite falling asleep on the sofa and missing chunks. Oh well, itâ€™s a DVD: we can always go back.

Oh yes: there was also a trip to Westfield, the time-void where hours go to die.

items.title: Looking Back and Forward
items.content_html:
My recent and forthcoming live music experiences all involve bands of my youth that have reformed and are touring their old material.1 Wallowing in nostalgia, some might call it.

But thereâ€™s nothing inherently wrong with bands getting back together. It can be problematic if you are the band that tours as the Dead Kennedys, of course. Thereâ€™s a whole saga there that I wonâ€™t go into, but if Jello Biafraâ€™s not involved, and in fact is actively against it, then itâ€™s not the Dead Kennedys.

Indeed, in his song â€œBuy My Snake Oilâ€ Jello suggested that a way for old punks to make money off their history would be to

Which is a fair criticism of old bands doing their thing in modern days, I guess. But I see two arguments to counter it, from a gig-goerâ€™s point of view.

Unfinished

The first was made by my friend Andrew, around the time that the Sex Pistols reformed and toured. This would have been in 1996.

â€œI missed them first time round,â€ he said when I challenged him about it. â€œThis is unfinished business for me.â€

Which was a good point, and kind of made me regret playing the purist and not going.

In 1993 I had investigated going to see the reunited Velvet Underground. But I really didnâ€™t want to see them at an all-seated venue. Partly because Iâ€™d had a bad experience seeing Lou Reed a year or so before (despite having had a very good experience with him a year or two before that).

I recall that I phoned the venue â€” Earlâ€™s Court, I think â€” and found that it did have some standing room. But those tickets were sold out. So I didnâ€™t go. Regretted that, too. So Iâ€™m taking the chance to see bands like the Rezillos, or The Beat and The Selecter, that I missed first time around.

OK, But What is it Really?

The second point about the â€œpunk nostalgia waveâ€ (or any similar accusation of nostalgia) is: that is not what it is.

Because hereâ€™s the thing: it isnâ€™t nostalgia if youâ€™re carrying on with something that was always there.

But this isnâ€™t that. Because while those bandsâ€™ heydays might have been in the past, their music has remained available and frequently-played. You canâ€™t be nostalgic for an album you listened to last week, or last night.

And a live performance always happens in the present.

This train of thought was kicked off for me a couple of years back when there was an article in the Guardian, prior to The Force Awakens coming out. I canâ€™t find it now,2 but it claimed that â€œnostalgiaâ€ was part of the cause of the excitement for the new film.

And I thought, no. Well, maybe for some people. But for many of us, if not most of us, Star Wars never went away. Weâ€™ve watched it, talked about it, read theories about it, and so on. It has been part of our lives.

Or take Doctor Who. Sure, there were the wilderness years before 2005, but The Doctor never really went away. The Tardis and Daleks are burned into Britainâ€™s cultural memory, and I think they always will be.

Now if I were to see an episode of, say, Marine Boy: that would be nostalgic. I remember it fondly from my childhood, and have never seen it since. Iâ€™ve never even seen it in colour, because those were the days of black & white televisions.3

But I canâ€™t be nostalgic for punk bands or Star Wars or Doctor Who, because they never went away. The sense of warmth and shared experience they bring: thatâ€™s not nostalgia, itâ€™s something else. Familiarity, at worst. Or better: community.

  1. Or a mixture of old and new, as with The Rezillos. ↩︎

  2. This is why you should always save links, folks. ↩︎

  3. God, I really come from another time, donâ€™t I? ↩︎

items.title: Punk and Hugo
items.content_html:
I hadnâ€™t come across Garageland London before, though I approve of the name.1 They came across my radar the other day with a piece called Cease and Desist: An open letter to Brewdog from PUNK, which says:

It has recently been brought to our attention that you are claiming legal ownership of the word â€˜punkâ€™ and are sending threatening legal notices to those you feel are infringing on that ownership by using that word.

I hadnâ€™t heard this about Brewdog. If itâ€™s true, theyâ€™re being beyond ridiculous (or possibly winding people up). Iâ€™ve got a lot of time for a Scottish company making craft beer, even if itâ€™s only OK (and too damn strong most of the time: I like a beer you can drink a few of without falling over). But like the Garageland people, I thought their â€œEquity for Punks investment portfolio did raise some eyebrows.â€

The open letter ends:

Definitions of punk are varied and debates over those definitions have been going on since before you were born. However, one thing punk is not is a bully! That goes against everything punk stands for. If you continue in this vein your punk credentials will be revoked and you will be called upon to cease and desist.

Kind regards and a middle finger salute

and is then signed by hundreds of bands. So many that I canâ€™t really believe the website got agreement from all of them. But I heartily endorse the message.

In other good news, the Hugo Awards nominations were announced, and it looks like a great list, and also like the Puppies have been almost totally wiped out this year. Yay fandom!

I also note that one of the novel nominees is the very Too Like the Lightning that I was writing about the other day. Hugo nominated, and you still canâ€™t buy it in Britain. Come on publishers!

Also: WordPress tells me that this is my 600th post on here. Not that many for the time the siteâ€™s been going for, but a milestone â€” or at least a round number â€” nonetheless.

items.title: Garden and Barbican
items.content_html:
Spent most of today in the garden, making a start on clearing it up for the summer. Not exactly gardening, as such. More gathering sticks and leaves, and putting them into brown bins for collection. Nice day for it, though.

Then this evening to the Barbican, for the New York Philharmonic doing a couple of pieces by John Adams, as part of the â€œJohn Adams at 70â€³ series. Oh, and in the middle they had a cello concerto by Esa-Pekka Salonen. Who was the cellist? Nobody special. Just Yo-Yo Ma.

It was clearly a virtuoso performance, but I didnâ€™t enjoy the Salonen nearly as much as I did the two Adams pieces. Especially the second, â€œHarmonielehre.â€ Among other things, itâ€™s good to see something orchestral where the percussionists have some serious work to do.

Not that we could see the percussionists, mostly. We were effectively in the front row. Which is to say, it was row D, but row C was right up against the front of the stage, and not being used because the stage had been extended into rows A and B. That orchestra is big. The downside of having such close seats is that you can only see the first few rows of the orchestra: the string sections, basically.

The big upside of the position, of course, is that you get such a close view and intimate sense of the performance. Itâ€™s almost like youâ€™re inside the music at times.

Meanwhile British politics has gone even crazier, with Michael Howard crawling out of the woodwork to threaten war with Spain.1 But thatâ€™s a discussion for another time.

  1. To be fair to Howard, thatâ€™s not at all what he said. Just that May should be as steadfast with Spain as Thatcher was with Argentina. But â€œwarâ€ is of course how the papers are hyping it. It wouldnâ€™t surprise me if Gibraltarians (96% remain) now wanted to become part of Spain. ↩︎

items.title: Homophobia in SF Fandom
items.content_text:
As well as being in charge of the website of the British Science Fiction Association (BSFA), I also admin the associationâ€™s Facebook group. Yesterday a member posted a link to the BBC story about the sexuality of the new companion in Doctor Who. â€œDoctor Who gets first openly gay companion,â€ it says. Nice to know, but no big deal in 2017, right?

Wrong, sadly. I woke to 81 comments on the FB post. Thatâ€™s a huge number by the normal standards of the group. Itâ€™s not very chatty. It turned out that a raving homophobe had stormed into the group and started to shout about the corruption of youth and I donâ€™t know what all. The comments were a combination of his, and of calmer and more tolerant heads both calling him out and trying to debate rationally with him. To no avail.

I had no choice â€” nor any desire â€” but to kick him out the group and block him. I wrote the following, and I thought I should preserve it here;

Iâ€™ve just had to eject a member from the group for making offensive remarks to other members. And worse, making remarks offensive to other members.

Specifically he was being offensive to all our LGBT members, and everyone who supports them, or who just supports humanity and common decency.
Oh, wait, thatâ€™s all the other members, isnâ€™t it?

Folks, I donâ€™t need to tell you this, but itâ€™s 2017. You can no longer argue that characters in popular TV programmes should not reflect the whole range of people in society. Nor can you make the argument that a characterâ€™s sexuality should have no place in Doctor Who, when it plainly has had a place at least since 2005.

Or donâ€™t these people remember Rose being in love with The Doctor? Martha pining over him? Hell, go back further: Jo went off and married a male ecologist. And Iâ€™m sure at least a couple of other female companions went off with guys.

Flaunting their heterosexuality.

We wonâ€™t get any of that with Bill, at least.

Unless the next Doctor is a woman.

items.title: Some Town
items.content_text:
Thereâ€™s a new podcast out from the makers of Serial. Seems like itâ€™s going to be very interesting.

Itâ€™s called S-Town, which stands for â€œshit town,â€ but I guess they donâ€™t want to put a swear in the title. They donâ€™t bleep anything out in the show, though.

Itâ€™s about a guy from rural Alabama who contacts reporter Brian Reed to tell him about the corruption in his town. Supposedly the Sheriffâ€™s department is so corrupt that a few years ago a son of a rich family murdered someone, and it was so thoroughly covered up that thereâ€™s no trace of it. Thatâ€™s what John says, anyway.

Eventually Reed starts to look into it, and the story begins. Iâ€™m only an episode and a half in and itâ€™s pretty compelling so far. There are seven episodes in total, and, Netflix-style, theyâ€™re all available now. Well worth a listen, Iâ€™d say.

items.title: The Night Before
items.content_text:
I couldnâ€™t let this night pass without acknowledging that tomorrow will be the start of us losing something great. In years to come the names of Cameron, May, Farage, Gove, etc, will be reviled, of course, but that doesnâ€™t help us now. It doesnâ€™t help us prevent the slide into the abyss of small-minded, inward-looking ugliness that I fear we are headed for.

I donâ€™t want to see these islands turning into the nightmare archipelago that they could if we let the insane clowns in government lead us into a cesspit of deregulation, rejection of human rights, and economic disaster.

I reject all that. I choose optimism.

I choose to believe that most people are basically decent and want the best for everyone, even if a small minority of them made a bad choice in voting, guided by liars.

I choose to believe that there is such a thing as progress in society, in culture. It isnâ€™t constant and it isnâ€™t guaranteed, but its arc does bend towards justice.

I choose to believe that the forces of backwardness â€” the racists, the misogynists, the homophobes, and everyone who condemns their fellow humans for what they are, what they believe, how they live or who they love â€” that those people will be washed up by the tides of history, left flapping on the shores of the future, and waste away.

Tomorrow we will still be in the European Union, but no longer of it. Brexit can still be stopped, but if it isnâ€™t, if it goes ahead at full crashing speed the way the Tories seem to want: I choose to believe that we can still be the open-minded, welcoming society that I know we are.

And one day, Europe, weâ€™ll come back.

This is what rhe trees in Hackney are looking like this spring.

items.title: Singles
items.content_html:
I was thinking about the loss of singles. Not individual tracks released individually: that still happens, of course; perhaps more than ever. But back in the days of actual, physical singles â€” 45 rpm records, or even CD singles later â€” you didnâ€™t just get an individual track.

Iâ€™m here to celebrate â€” and maybe mourn the loss of â€” the B-side.

When you bought a single you usually knew what the main song was going to be, because you had heard it on the radio, or at least read a review. Or you might just know and trust the artistâ€™s work, and believe that the chosen track would be worth your 75p.1

But there was always the promise that there would be something good on the other side, too.

Often, of course, the B-side track was really â€œBâ€ quality, or lower. It was genuinely just filler. Which was always a shame. I remember flipping Elvis Costelloâ€™s â€œOliverâ€™s Army,â€ to find out what â€œMy Funny Valentineâ€ was like. I hated it, and never listened to it again. Though as (in other versions) itâ€™s something of a jazz classic, itâ€™s possible that Iâ€™d like it more now.

The Membersâ€™ classic â€œThe Sound of the Suburbsâ€ was backed by something called â€œHandling the Big Jets,â€ which always sounded slightly rude to us2 and I think was an instrumental.

But for every one of those you could get a â€œJail Guitar Doors,â€3 or a â€œThe Prisoner.â€4 Or almost any Beatles single.

Then there were double A-sides, wherein both sides were supposed to be worthy of being playlisted. They always felt like slightly better value for your hard-earned pocket money.

And when CD singles came along they usually had three tracks, raising them arguably into the EP category.

But now, tracks are realised for streaming or download, completely on their own. Itâ€™s very sad, and Iâ€™m sure they must feel lonely. Plus if youâ€™re buying the download and you want what would have been the B-side, you have to pay for each individual track.

I was going to say, as well, that if you search for single on your streaming service of choice, you only get one track. But I found out the other day thatâ€™s not quite true. I wanted to listen to â€œElephant Stone,â€ by the Stone Roses; and in fact the B-side, â€œThe Hardest Thing In the Worldâ€ was listed too. Its â€œAlbumâ€ tag was given as â€œElephant Stone â€” Single (2009)â€.

Which apart from the wrong date (and ok, it couldâ€™ve been a reissue 5) is not a bad example of misused metadata. Or maybe just misnamed: not every gathering or carrier of a group of songs or musical pieces is an â€œalbumâ€.

Or maybe thatâ€™s just a change of meaning: what we used to call a single or an EP is now just a very short album.

  1. Only 50p, in fact, when I first bought them. ↩︎

  2. We were schoolboys. ↩︎

  3. The B-side of â€œClash City Rockers,â€ of course. ↩︎

  4. B-side of â€œ(White Man) In Hammersmith Palais.â€ What, you think Iâ€™m not going to talk about Clash singles? ↩︎

  5. But how you should give the date for reissues is a whole nother conversation ↩︎

items.title: Publishers and Sinners
items.content_text:
Borrowing that title from (what used to be) a regular section in Dave Langfordâ€™s Ansible newsletter.

The publishing sin in question, though, is quite astonishingly egregious, if the story is true. And I have no reason to doubt it.

Thereâ€™s a book called Too Like the Lightning, by Ada Palmer. I read a review of it a year or so back and thought it sounded really interesting. But I didnâ€™t get round to trying to get it at the time.

Something reminded me of it recently, and I tracked it down, at least to the publisherâ€™s site that I linked to there. But I wanted to buy a copy on Kindle, and Amazon had no sign of it. This is relatively rare nowadays. Especially in SF, surely.

I tried again a couple of times, but to no avail. There are a few chapters available on the Tor website; and they were one of the first major publishers to really push ebooks without DRM, so youâ€™d expect something there, but no.

I think you can get a Nook copy at the site above, but Nook? I mean, come on.

Anyway, eventually I duckducked in the modern style, which is to say I just typed the question: â€œwhy is â€˜too like the lightningâ€™ not available on kindleâ€.

I was led to a Reddit AMA with the author, wherein she said this:

That [making the book available on the UK Kindle store] can only happen if a UK publisher decides to publish it. Unfortunately UK publishers rarely publish female SF authors; a lot of them feel strongly that only male SF authors are likely to sell. If you want it to come out in the UK Kindle store, the best option is to write a quick e-mail to a couple of your favorite UK SP publishers to tell them youâ€™re eager for these books â€” hearing from readers makes a big difference when publishers are considering picking up an author for localization.

Emphasis mine. If this is true â€” and again, I have no reason to doubt her word â€” I am beyond horrified that such an attitude can be prevalent at UK publishers. In 2017.

Obviously what I want to do now is to buy a physical copy, here in the UK. Itâ€™s listed on Amazon UK, but itâ€™s not clear whether itâ€™s an import from the US, or what. (Also very strange is the authorâ€™s credit in that entry: â€œAssistant Professor of History Ada Palmer.â€ It even makes it into the URL.)

As well as blatant sexism, this is an example of the ridiculous regionalism that publishers still try to force onto the internet age. Also film and TV companies. Luckily Apple stopped the music business doing that.

Bits donâ€™t see borders. And neither should we. But thatâ€™s very much another conversation.

Actually, you know what Iâ€™m going to do? Iâ€™m going to see if I can order it from my local bookshop. Support your local, as well as fight sexism in a small way.

items.title: Podcast Ads and Pricing
items.content_html:
Podcast adverts are the least offensive of all types of advertising. Because even though theyâ€™re in your ears, theyâ€™re not in your face.

Iâ€™m talking, here, about the sponsorship kind, wherein the podcast host reads some ad copy in their own voice. Sometimes copy supplied by the company, sometimes their own words. Sometimes they just read plainly, sometimes itâ€™s more entertaining.

But itâ€™s always relevant and vetted. Iâ€™m more likely to look at the product or service mentioned in a podcast that I listen to regularly than any thatâ€™s advertised on a website. Especially if the website uses a popup.

And if you donâ€™t want to listen to the sponsorâ€™s message, podcast players make it very easy to skip forward.1

One organisation that has been sponsoring a lot lately is Away Travel. They make a range of modern, four-wheel, hardshell suitcases. Their carry-on versions have the innovation of including a battery and a couple of USB ports, so you can charge your phone, iPad, etc, while youâ€™re at the airport.2

They seem like they make a pretty good product. But the strange thing is that the podcast hosts all stress how inexpensive the cases are. But theyâ€™re not. The biggest one is nearly Â£300. John Lewis sells a similar Samsonite model for Â£179, for example.

Itâ€™s possible that the Away one is tougher, of course. Impossible to tell without seeing them side by side. But I donâ€™t think Away should be trying to sell themselves on cheapness when theyâ€™re significantly more expensive than a high-end brand. Embrace the expense; go for the luxury market. Or something.

It works for Apple.

  1. Unless youâ€™re using AirPods, I guess. ↩︎

  2. Or elsewhere, obviously. But airports, with the long time you spend waiting around in them, are notorious burners of batteries. ↩︎

items.title: Laptop Ban Stranger Than I Thought
items.content_text:
Todayâ€™s Washington Post WorldView newsletter throws more light, a lot of shade, and a lot more confusion onto the ban I linked to last night, on taking laptops and tablets in hand luggage from certain airports.

First, I didnâ€™t realise that the list of affected airports is different between the UK and the US. Second, for the US, it is just a small set of airports, not all airports in the affected countries. The UK takes the broader approach â€” but for a different set of countries.

The most interesting point to my mind is that this may all be Trump trying to help American businesses:

When pressed by reporters, officials in both countries said the measures were not a response to a specific threat, but rather the result of intelligence assessmentsÂ that concluded groups like the IslamicÂ State and al-Qaeda are seeking new methods to sow terror in the skies, possibly through hidden bombs in electronic equipment.

And later:

Farrell and Newman suggested Tuesdayâ€™s order is an example of the Trump administration â€œweaponizing interdependenceâ€ â€” using its leverage in a world where American airports are key â€œnodesâ€ inÂ global air travel to weaken competitors. My colleague Max Bearak detailed how this could be a part of Trumpâ€™s wider protectionist agenda. In February, President Trump met with executives of U.S. airlines and pledged that he would help them compete against foreign carriers that receive subsidies from their home governments.

â€œA lot of that competition is subsidized by governments, big league,â€ said Trump at that meeting. â€œIâ€™ve heard that complaint from different people in this room. Probably about one hour after I got elected, I was inundated with calls from your industry and many other industries, because itâ€™s a very unfair situation.â€

So unfair. But if thatâ€™s whatâ€™s behind it, what the hell does our glorious leader get out of going along with a slightly modified version of it? Itâ€™s certainly not to protect British airlines, as they (unlike American airlines) are affected by the ban. Maybe my â€œlapdogâ€ dig was exactly right. For years Tony Blair was referred too as George W Bushâ€™s poodle. Maybe Theresa May is adopting the same role for Trump. Which is a horrifying thought.

Another WaPo article contradicts all that, though, suggesting that the whole thing might be based on some credible concerns:

The U.S. restrictions were prompted by a growing concern within the government that terrorists who have long sought to develop hard-to-detect bombs hidden inside electronic devices may have put renewed effort into that work, according to people familiar with the matter

But it asks the question and fails to get a satisfactory answer, â€œWhy not ban all electronics on flights, then?â€

People familiar with the discussions said the restrictions were designed to defeat the particular type of threat that is of greatest concern: the possibility that terrorists could smuggle explosives inside electronics and manually detonate them once on a plane.

Even if that makes sense (after all, its not like a computer in the hold is (or could hide) some kind of timing device): why just from a strange subset of airports, even in the countries of concern?

And if itâ€™s all based on a real threat, why the US/UK difference?

They also raise the real concern that journalists, activists, and just ordinary citizens, will be separated from their personal information, leaving it under the control of unknown people.

Buckle up, folks, this ride is only going to get stranger and more unpleasant.

items.title: Stupid Fawning Lapdog Government Apes the US Again
items.content_text:
Our glorious leaders have seen fit to copy Trump and his cronies with banning laptops and tablets on planes â€” from certain countries. The only possible reason for this madness is to punish people for coming from (or visiting) those countries.

Worse, though: such a ban is only going to:

  1. make things even more confusing and complex at airport security, and
  2. get extended until it covers all flights, everywhere. You wait and see.

items.title: Mandatory Options
items.content_html:
Where Iâ€™m working at the moment weâ€™re using a tool called Splunk for some log file viewing and analysis. I hadnâ€™t come across it, though apparently itâ€™s quite well known.

So wanting to know a bit more about it, I thought Iâ€™d have a run through of their tutorial. To do that you have to sign up for an account. Thatâ€™s fine, itâ€™s free, thereâ€™s no obligation. Iâ€™ve signed up for plenty of things.

Exceptâ€¦ well, look:

That little â€œYes, I want to receiveâ€¦â€ checkbox looks like a fairly standard opt-in. The kind we always opt out of. But look at it. Look at its reddish border. The asterisk. These are fairly standard1 ways of indicating that a field is mandatory.

A mandatory opt-in checkbox.

A mandatory option.

After grabbing that screenshot I closed the page. How not to get people to sign up.

  1. Though the red is bad UI/UX, because it doesnâ€™t work well for people with colour-blindness. ↩︎

items.title: Reading Materials
items.content_text:
Youâ€™re probably wondering whatâ€™s happened to my books posts. Surely I must have read something since January (and I thought Iâ€™d posted about two books this year, but apparently not).

Thing is, after the Twin Peaks book, I started something rather large. Iâ€™m over 200 pages in, which means Iâ€™m about one-sixth of the way through it.

It is Alan Mooreâ€™s Jerusalem: a monster hardback with tiny print. I picked it up when I went to see him interviewed by Stewart Lee, back in November. I could have got either the hardback or a slipcased three-volume paperback version. Almost as soon as I started reading I wished Iâ€™d gone for the latter, because itâ€™s so damn heavy to hold.

So itâ€™ll take me quite a while till Iâ€™m ready to write about it. Iâ€™m thoroughly enjoying it, though.

items.title: Vanessa Bell and Princess Leia
items.content_text:
We went to Dulwich Picture Gallery today, to see both the permanent collection and the Vanessa Bell exhibition. All very fine. But I was struck by one of Bellâ€™s paintings in particular.

Itâ€™s called â€œThe Model,â€ which makes it hard to search for, being so generic. But itâ€™s clear to me that the hair & makeup people of the original Star Wars must have been familiar with it, since it is totally where they got Princess Leiaâ€™s headphone hairstyle.

Bell lived until 1961, so her work is still in copyright, which I expect is why itâ€™s hard to find a decent image online, but Google Image Search has this.

Take a look. Tell me Iâ€™m wrong.

items.title: The Return of SonoAir
items.content_html:
Back in January I wrote about trying to play podcasts through the Sonos. As youâ€™ll recall1 I had tried and failed to install AirSonos on my NAS, and was considering trying SonoAir on my Mac.

I did try it, but it never quite worked. The app launched, and found the Sonos network and the speaker. But it didnâ€™t appear as an AirPlay device to my phone. I could make it work in one context: iTunes (on the same Mac) could see it and use it as a functional output device.But that wasnâ€™t much use, as the Sonos already has access to my iTunes library from where itâ€™s backed up on the NAS â€” and also to Apple Music. So being able to play from iTunes to the Sonos brought nothing new.

The added functionality I was looking for was to be able to play podcasts from Overcast, and switch to the speaker when Iâ€™m listening in the kitchen. For that my iPhone or iPad needs to be able to see the speaker.

So it all didnâ€™t look too promising. But I was just having another go, and I noticed that the version on the website is 1.0 (BETA 6.1), while I had BETA 4. A quick download and weâ€™re up and running: it works!

Now I just have to keep my MacBook running at all times. Oh well.

  1. I know, you probably wonâ€™t. ↩︎

items.title: Missed
items.content_html:
Well, yesterday genuinely feels like the first day Iâ€™ve missed posting this year. A few post-midnight posts have counted towards the previous day, but although Iâ€™m writing this early in the morning, itâ€™s definitely the 16th.

Itâ€™s for a good reason, though: I went to the pub after work.1

The occasion was the monthly drinks for ex- and still-current-Misys people. Always good to see folk I havenâ€™t seen for a while. And Misys are in the news at the moment. It looks like my old section, Payments & Messaging, wonâ€™t be long for this world (even what little is left of it). This D+H outfit â€” Vista, the owners of Misys, have bought them and are planning to smoosh them together with Misys â€” is big in payments. Iâ€™d expect that their products will be seen as superior, and our Payment Manager will start to be sunsetted.

Thatâ€™s certainly the likely trajectory if Misys management end up running the combined organisation. They have a permanent, severe case of inverse not-invented-here syndrome. Any product that the company has been making and selling successfully for years (decades, in the case of Midas and Equation) is automatically suspect and needs to be edged out in favour of something that came from another company, and/or is newer and less capable.

Mind you, those old products have a habit of keeping on keeping on (and making the company money). Because, of course, they meet the needs of customers.

Not that anyone was talking about that at the pub.

  1. I did start to write something when I got home, but it was never going to be anything viable. Looking at it this morning it doesnâ€™t even make sense. ↩︎

items.title: Wiretaps and Wipeouts
items.content_text:
Couple of thoughts about the news, tonight. First of all, CNN reports on Kellyanne Conway, Trumpâ€™s â€œcounselor,â€ and her strange thoughts about microwaves:

â€œWhat I can say is there are many ways to surveil each other,â€ Conway said, before suggesting that surveillance could take place through phones, TVs or â€œmicrowaves that turn into cameras.â€

I want one of these magic microwaves. I mean, think about it: you can reheat your leftovers, then take a photograph of them and post it to Instagram. All from the same device.

More sanely (at least slightly) they seem to be backing off from the nonsensical wiretapping accusations. According to Sean Spicer, the Whitehouse press secretary:

â€œThe President used the word wiretaps in quotes to mean, broadly, surveillance and other activitiesâ€

So thatâ€™s OK, then.

In another article they treat it all more seriously, pointing out that doing down your predecessors is a tactic of dictators everywhere:

They, too, use the apparatus of government to support their whims. And worse, they also seek to punish their predecessors in office and political opponents â€” as we have seen in countries from Iran to Zambia to, of course, Russia.

How long until we hear Trump surrogates suggest that Obama might be guilty of a crime?

Closer to home, the UK governmentâ€™s Mayhem programme involved them forcing through the Brexit bill, so weâ€™re teetering along the slippery slope, getting ready to run towards the cliff of deadly metaphors.

Jeremy Corbyn has things in hand, though. He tweeted:

Deeply disappointing that govt denied the people, through Parliament, Brexit oversight & refused to guarantee the rights of EU nationals

â€” Jeremy Corbyn MP (@jeremycorbyn) March 13, 2017

We will continue to demand that the stress they, and Brits in the EU, are being put under is ended, and they are given the right to remain

â€” Jeremy Corbyn MP (@jeremycorbyn) March 13, 2017

Labour at every stage will challenge govt plans for a bargain basement Brexit with our alternative that puts jobs & living standards first

â€” Jeremy Corbyn MP (@jeremycorbyn) March 13, 2017

This is the same Jeremy Corbyn who, just a few weeks ago, put a three-line whip in place to make his MPs vote in favour of the initial version of the bill â€” which is identical to the version that has now been passed, since the Lordsâ€™ amendments were all rolled back.

I voted for him as leader, twice, but I regret it now, Iâ€™ve got to say. Heâ€™s a decent guy, and I agree with him on many â€” even most â€” issues. But on this, the most important thing facing our country today, leading to potentially the biggest disaster since the Second World War, heâ€™s been completely useless. Worse: complicit.

items.title: Broadchurch Thoughts
items.content_text:
I hope everyoneâ€™s following the new series of Broadchurch. If you thought the second season didnâ€™t live up to the first, then I think youâ€™ll find that the third brings it back to greatness. Trilogies always sag in the middle, donâ€™t they?

People are being very positive about it on Twitter. Many of the comments are around how every guy you see is a possible suspect. Which is very true. Iâ€™m just glad to discover that there are eight episodes, not six as I had thought. Which means weâ€™re still not quite halfway through.

David Tennant and Olivia Coleman are fantastic together as ever. and Jodie Whittaker as Beth is amazing.

Most of all, I think it bodes well for Chris Chibnallâ€™s future role as head writer on Doctor Who.

items.title: And Then it Was All That
items.content_text:
One of the blogs I follow is called And now itâ€™s all this, by the mysterious Dr Drang. He writes mainly on engineering and provides lots of interesting Python scripts.

What Iâ€™m interested in his blogâ€™s title and subtitle, though. â€œAnd now itâ€™s all thisâ€; and â€œI just said what I said and it was wrong. Or was taken wrong.â€ Iâ€™ve been reading it for years, and had only idly wondered about why it was called that, or what it really meant.

Iâ€™ve also been listening to, and reading about, The Beatles for years â€” for a great many more years. And so I was very familiar with John Lennonâ€™s â€œmore popular than Jesusâ€ line, and the subsequent furore.

But not that familiar, it turns out. Or not with his apology, at least.

We recently watched the excellent Eight Days a Week film, which has lots of Beatles footage Iâ€™d never seen before, and puts it all together into a compelling narrative.

Of course, it covers the â€œJesusâ€ period. So there was John, at a press conference, making an apology of sorts. And out pops:

I just said what I said and it was wrong. Or was taken wrong. And now itâ€™s all this.

Oh. OK. Right. I should have seen that years ago.

Of course there are two remaining questions:

  1. Why did the good doctor choose to name his blog that?
  2. And what does the â€œleancrewâ€ mean in his domain name?

items.title: Saved Life
items.content_html:
In International Clash Day I mentioned a life-changing song: â€œWasted Life,â€ by Stiff Little Fingers. SLFâ€™s anti-military song literally changed my life; or its potential direction, at least. I was probably moving in an anti-war kind of direction anyway, to be fair, but it was definitely a trigger point.

People say â€” or used they to, at least â€” that a song couldnâ€™t change your life. By comparison, I donâ€™t think there was ever a similar tendency to say that a book couldnâ€™t change a personâ€™s life. I suspect that is down to their comparative sizes: it seems respectable for something the size of a novel to have a major impact on a humanâ€™s psyche, while a three-minute song? Not so much.

Although if it were merely length, then people wouldnâ€™t have complained if you said an album changed your life. Iâ€™m not sure that anyone ever said that,1 but I suspect that if they had, their statement would have been pooh-poohed just as much as the same claim for a song.

At this point I feel I ought to quote Springsteen, giving the opposite view:

We learned more from a three-minute record, baby, Than we ever learned in school

he sings in â€œNo Surrender.â€ Hyperbole, certainly, but there is a core of truth to it: the truth of the feeling you can get from listening to a great song.

With â€œWasted Lifeâ€ the feeling for me was of sudden crystallisation, or realisation. I had, for some years, been saying that I wanted to be pilot, join the RAF. This was before the horrors of the Gulf War, or for that matter the Balkans. Though it was in the heart of the Cold War, and British soldiers were stationed in Northern Ireland during the troubles â€” though not so much RAF staff, I would think.

But I was blind to all that, brought up as I was on a diet of Second World War films, Commando comics, and Airfix models of warplanes. I had, in short, a thoroughly romanticised view of war. And I just wanted to fly.

But I didnâ€™t want to kill. I had always known that, Iâ€™m sure. But two lines of that one song made it real for me:

Stuff their fucking armies Killing isnâ€™t my idea of fun2

And that was all it took. I remember that it was a while before I could tell my parents that I had changed my plans. Perhaps because they would have asked why, and I didnâ€™t want to have to explain it. Maybe because I thought theyâ€™d be disappointed. Iâ€™m sure my Mum wasnâ€™t. My Dad kind of was: â€œBut you were going to be a Spanish-speaking pilot,â€ he said. He had always been slightly amused that my school taught half of us Spanish, instead of the then-much-more-conventional French.

A life can hinge on such a small moment.

  1. Somebody must have, of course. ↩︎

  2. In an amusing followup to recent thoughts, I originally wrote that as â€œarmy,â€ but find that lyrics sites think this plural too. Correctly, of course. ↩︎

items.title: Whether You Want To Or Not
items.content_html:
“Write even when you don’t want to,” say some people encouraging us to write every day. That would be me right now. The “don’t want to” part, not the “encouraging” part. It’s late and I haven’t written anything yet and I’ve made this daily rod for my own back.

On the other hand, I do love to write, and I can’t deny that I’ve done more of it in this last couple of months.

Though, not, as I hoped I might, any more fiction. I’m still stalled in the middle of the novel which in idea, at least is nearly five years old. It’ll be starting school soon!

And I need to get round to submitting some of the other, finished, things I have. Because they’re no use just sitting here on my hard solid-state drive.

items.title: Stiff Little Memories
items.content_text:
Iâ€™ve just had two slightly odd experiences while researching Stiff Little Fingers.

SLF were the first band I ever saw live, and they had a major effect on my life â€” which is why I was researching them: Iâ€™m writing a longer piece about the effect they had on me.

So as I was reading the Wikipedia article about them, I became somewhat confused. Because it says they split up in 1983, and reformed in 1987. Now the breakup Iâ€™d forgotten about, but it seems right. However, I saw them on the tour in 87. I saw them two days in a row. I had tickets for the Brixton Academy gig, which I think was on a Saturday, and then when Time Out came out that week there was a small advert in the back (Iâ€™ve no idea how I came to see it), which said:

Tin Soldiers
Belfastâ€™s finest. Shhh: a secret gig!

Or something very like that. It was on the Friday night at the Mean Fiddler. Which I donâ€™t think I had ever been to at that time, and which was a bastard long way from Tooting. But I wasnâ€™t going to miss the chance to see SLF in a small club.

What I mainly remember was that the Academy gig the next night was a bit of a letdown after the intensity of seeing them at the Mean Fiddler.

But anyway, the point of all of this is that as far as I remember things, this all was â€” or was billed as â€” their farewell tour. Thatâ€™s why the t-shirt (which I still have) says â€œGame Over.â€

Now obviously theyâ€™re around again, and Iâ€™ve seen them since, and bought albums theyâ€™ve released since. But my memory says they broke up in 87 (or it could have been 88, but I think not (though actually March 88 if this setlist site is to be believed)), and then reformed later. But Wikipedia and All Music both say Iâ€™m wrong.

I donâ€™t know. Who would you trust?

Actually probably not me. Iâ€™m becoming more convinced as I look at that setlist site, that I must have seen them several times at the Academy, after moving to London in 87, and the supposed farewell tour must have been later. In which case the Mean Fiddler was a bastard long way from Walthamstow, but thatâ€™s still true.

The second odd experience was that I clicked onto the Wikipedia talk page to see whether the history was disputed at all. It isnâ€™t, but around five sections in thereâ€™s a section entitled â€œthe?â€, in which someone asks whether they were ever referred to as â€œthe Stiff Little Fingers.â€

And back in 2007 some guy called â€œDevilgateâ€ answered firmly in the negative.

items.title: Little, Feat...
items.content_html:
Many songs these days involve one or more other artists guesting with the main one. Rappers adding a part to a singerâ€™s track, for example. Nowadays such guests are always credited. Quite rightly: weâ€™ve come a long way from the days when Billy Preston played keyboards on some Beatles songs uncredited (though visible in the famous Apple Records rooftop performance).

As featured artists, such guests are nearly always credited using the abbreviation â€œfeat.â€ â€œThe Beatles feat Billy Preston,â€ to give an example that was never used.

But â€œfeatâ€ is a word on itâ€™s own, of course, as well as an abbreviation. Which I think may be why I always find the formation slightly amusing. And there used to be a band called Little Feat, if Iâ€™m not very much mistaken (Iâ€™ve never knowingly heard them).

So Iâ€™ve been wondering how the modern crediting style would have worked if they had ever been guests, or had featured guests, on any of their songs. â€œLittle Feat feat Joe Feet.â€ â€œLegs & Co feat Little Feat.â€1

Alas, it was not the way back then. Though their Wikipedia article suggests theyâ€™re still around, so it could happen.

More surprisingly it tells us that they changed â€œFeetâ€ to â€œFeatâ€ as a â€œhomage to the Beatles.â€2 I had no inkling of that connection when I mentioned the Beatles above.

  1. Yes, I know Legs & Co were dancers. Iâ€™m just trying to make up mildly amusing names. I invented Joe Feet. ↩︎

  2. Iâ€™m assuming that refers to the story of the Beatles naming that involved them wanting an insect name like Buddy Holly & the Crickets, but changing the spelling so it read as beat music. ↩︎

items.content_text:
In What Writers Really Do When They Write George Saunders gives a great insight into some parts of his working process.

What does an artist do, mostly? She tweaks that which sheâ€™s already done. There are those moments when we sit before a blank page, but mostly weâ€™re adjusting that which is already there. The writer revises, the painter touches up, the director edits, the musician overdubs.

Or â€œWriting is rewriting,â€ as someone once put it.[^heming] Itâ€™s a good piece, and well worth reading. Oddly, in the printed edition (Saturdayâ€™s Guardian Review section) it was entitled â€œMaster of the Universe.â€ [^heming]: Hard to find who, but it seems to have been Hemingway. Whose writing I donâ€™t like, but that doesnâ€™t mean he was wrong.

items.title: Pivoting Around Words
items.content_text:
I should start a new category here, for word-use. In fact, having written that, I just have: language (hopefully that link will work once I publish this).

Today I want to talk about the word â€œpivot.â€ As you know, pivot has come, over the last few years, to mean change direction, especially in a political context. A recent example from the New Yorker: Donâ€™t Be Fooled. Donald Trump Didnâ€™t Pivot.

It sort of makes sense, but like many knew usages, I canâ€™t help but wonder why it has come into this use.

And for this one I also canâ€™t help but wonder to what extent Friends is responsible.

Youâ€™ll know the episode Iâ€™m thinking of, if youâ€™ve seen it: Ross is moving in to a new apartment, and being too cheap to pay the delivery charge, ropes Rachel in to help him move a sofa. Inevitably they get stuck on the stairs, and he keeps shouting at her, â€œPivot! Pivot!â€ to try to get her to turn the sofa in an unspecified direction.

Of course, he might have been using it quite precisely: the sofa probably needed to rotate about a fixed point, which is what â€œpivotâ€ originally meant.

What it has come to mean, in politics, is a change of direction less than a U-turn (or flip-flop); but still quite a substantial one. I suppose it has a sense of turning without moving forward at the same time. Though I may be overthinking it there. Itâ€™s quite descriptive, but it seems like it has becoming ubiquitous incredibly quickly; and is already practically a cliche.

Of course thatâ€™s just my view of the optics of the thing.

items.title: Reassessing
items.content_html:
I never cared that much for Joe Cockerâ€™s highly-rated cover of â€œWith A Little Help From My Friends,â€ but I just saw it on BBC Fourâ€™s â€¦ Sings the Beatles, a programme whose title tells you exactly what itâ€™s about.

Andâ€¦ hell, yeah: itâ€™s really good. Apparently Steve Winwood and Jimmy Page are on the recording. But we wonâ€™t hold that against it.1 Sometimes all you need is the passage of time; sometimes itâ€™s just about the mood youâ€™re in. But itâ€™s often worth giving things another chance.2

Now itâ€™s on Petula Clarkâ€™s weird-arse version of â€œSergeant Pepperâ€™s Lonely Hearts Club Band,â€ during which the caption tells us that Petula is Britainâ€™s best-selling ever female artist. Iâ€™m guessing this was made before Adele.

  1. What? The Punk Wars never ended. ↩︎

  2. I guess. But how far do you go? Napoleon Dynamite? I think not. ↩︎

items.content_text:
Having looked again over yesterdayâ€™s piece, Iâ€™ve had a slight change of heart.

As Iâ€™m sure you noticed, I made a comment in the footnote to the effect that I thought that my misremembering of Neuromancerâ€˜s famous opening line was better than the actual one. I no longer think thatâ€™s the case.

Gibson obviously knew what he was doing. â€œThe sky above the portâ€ is more euphonious than my â€œover the port.â€

Glad we got that sorted out.

items.title: Under the Television Skies
items.content_html:
In The Colour of Television Jack Deighton questions the worth of the famous opening line of William Gibsonâ€™s Neuromancer:

The sky above the port was the colour of television, tuned to a dead channel.1

Jack questions its meaning, and describes it as â€œan author, straining, unsuccessfully, for effect.â€ I commented:

[D]onâ€™t take it so literally. It was obviously meant to mean â€œthe screen of a television set,â€ but writingâ€™s all about deleting unnecessary words, as Orwell told us.

I always took it to mean a stormy grey sky. Not literally speckled like an old telly on a channel where there was only static, but that was certainly what he was going for. Imagine that roiling, churning, grey-black-white melange, converted into a sky of a similar colour palette.

Itâ€™s so evocative, so memorable, itâ€™s almost poetry.

Plus thereâ€™s The Doors connection:

I also always took it as reference to the Doorsâ€™ song â€œMy Eyes Have Seen You,â€ that goes, â€œâ€¦ under the television sky! Television sky!â€

Lyrics sites â€” and my ears, this evening â€” say itâ€™s actually plural: â€œtelevision skies!â€ But that doesnâ€™t make any difference.

Anyway, Iâ€™ve always loved it â€” that opening, in particular. I mean, Iâ€™m fond of the book, but donâ€™t go back to it that often; but the opening is unforgettable.2

In having a look around before writing this, I discovered that thereâ€™s an extract on Gibsonâ€™s site, which reminds me that its all that good. Reading that extract, what think of most is the beats, or Hunter S Thompson.

And interestingly it isnâ€™t done with the sky after the first line:

you couldnâ€™t see the lights of Tokyo for the glare of the television sky

and:

By day, the bars down Ninsei were shuttered and featureless, the neon dead, the holograms inert, waiting, under the poisoned silver sky.

Which last point suggests that Jackâ€™s over-literal concern about the meaning of the opening might have an answer: maybe the sky was literally that staticy colour of an old TV between channels. If so, I donâ€™t think we ever got a reason for it. But itâ€™s implied there has been at least one war in the not-too-distant past of the novel.

Opening lines are so important. To my mind Gibsonâ€™s is up there on that bright, cold day in April, just around Barstow on the edge of the desert, with an exploding grandmother.

But to each their own, of course.

  1. I always remember it as â€œâ€¦ over the portâ€¦â€, which frankly I think is better. ↩︎

  2. Even if I misremember it, as described previously. ↩︎

Reading that extract, what think of most is the beats, or Hunter S Thompson. And interestingly it isnâ€™t done with the sky after the first line: > you couldnâ€™t see the lights of Tokyo for the glare of the television sky and: > By day, the bars down Ninsei were shuttered and featureless, the neon dead, the holograms inert, waiting, under the poisoned silver sky. Which last point suggests that Jackâ€™s over-literal concern about the meaning of the opening might have an answer: maybe the sky was literally that staticy colour of an old TV between channels. If so, I donâ€™t think we ever got a reason for it. But itâ€™s implied there has been at least one war in the not-too-distant past of the novel. Opening lines are so important. To my mind Gibsonâ€™s is up there on that bright, cold day in April, just around Barstow on the edge of the desert, with an exploding grandmother. But to each their own, of course. items.title: Tory MP Claims Astrology Could Help the NHS
items.content_text:
This should be enough to disbar someone from public life for good: Astrology could help take pressure off NHS doctors, claims Conservative MP â€” The Guardian. Though I notice the article is two years old. It just came to my attention via Facebook one of Twitterâ€™s occasional emails.

David Tredinnick said astrology, along with complementary medicine, could take pressure off NHS doctors, but acknowledged that any attempt to spend taxpayersâ€™ money on consulting the stars would cause â€œa huge rowâ€.

Getting his defence in early, he goes on to say that his likely critics (he names Brian Cox specifically):

â€œâ€¦ are also ignorant, because they never study the subject and just say that it is all to do with what appears in the newspapers, which it is not, and they are deeply prejudiced, and racially prejudiced, which is troubling.â€

Nice tactic: he knows heâ€™s talking bullshit, so accuses people of racism. Last time I checked, astrology wasnâ€™t a race.

Nor was stupidity.

And in the unlikely event that anyone reading this thinks Iâ€™m just being reflexively mean and as bad as the critics he fears, hereâ€™s a considered scientific opinion. The only possible known way the positions of the planets and stars at our birth could affect us is by gravity. And while gravity does travel all through the universe, it is very, very weak â€” the weakest of the fundamental forces. Just look at how hard it was to measure gravitational waves. We were only able to do that in the last year, and it took colliding black holes to make enough of a splash for us to measure.

Is it possible that heavenly bodies affect us in some other, as yet unknown way? Yes. And hereâ€™s what science says about that: show us how, and weâ€™ll study it. Demonstrate the mechanism by which this influence happens, and weâ€™ll write down the equations that govern it and learn all about it. Weâ€™ll have to throw out all existing models of physics, but if you bring the evidence, thatâ€™s what weâ€™ll do.

Thatâ€™s science.

items.title: More Network Nonsense
items.content_text:
More trouble with the home network today. We had a smart electricity meter installed a few days ago. Though without the â€œsmartâ€ part, because they couldnâ€™t get a good enough signal down in our basement. Youâ€™d think theyâ€™d have considered that possibility in designing them, since thatâ€™s the kind of place where a lot of peopleâ€™s meters are. Anyway, I think it was interfering with our powerline connection.

We have a BT HomeHub as our main router and connection out to the fibre. But the wifi was a bit crap up at the top of house. So about a year back I got a couple of powerline connectors and used them to extend the 5GHz network upstairs, using another router that we had accidentally acquired as the other access point.

It worked fine, until just the other day. The first symptom was that the Sonos app couldnâ€™t connect to the speaker. I did some diagnosis, and everything was just weird. We could mostly connect to the outside world without any trouble, but I couldnâ€™t connect to the HomeHubâ€™s web interface by name. Nor, I think, by IP address. And then in one of my experiments I tried a slightly different IP address (one that shouldnâ€™t have existed on our network), and I found myself atâ€¦ a Sky box.

Now you know my dislike for that bunch. Thereâ€™s no way Iâ€™d let their networking hardware on my LAN, any more than Iâ€™d subscribe to their channels. and in any case, just, what?

I wondered if our network could somehow have got crossed with one of the neighboursâ€™. But it seemed so improbable. The neighbouring network would need to be using the same SSID, at the very least.

As youâ€™d imagine, I started taking components out to try to isolate the problem. With just the BT HomeHub in place, things were back to normal. But as soon as I began adding parts, everything went weird.

Eventually I concluded â€” guessed, really â€” that the smart meter might be using powerline itself. Weâ€™re supposed to get a screen-based device for monitoring usage, and maybe that communicates with the meter over powerline. And the meter could have an embedded sky router? That seems unlikely, but maybe Sky have the contract to do the phoning home for EDF.

Anyway, since the root of the problem seemed to be at least partly to do with IP address conflicts, I decided to factory-reset everything and rebuild with a different IP address range (Iâ€™ve never used 172.16.0.0 before). Along with a new wifi SSID and password.

And so far so good. But Iâ€™m having trouble getting the second router to route properly via the first, so upstairs is going to be problematic till I can solve that.

All this is doing, of course, is making me wish that we could get Eeros in the UK. A self-configuring mesh network is exactly what we need, and not all this jerry-rigged nonsense.

items.title: â€œPingâ€ Pong
items.content_text:
When the original Unix designers (or, as it turns out, Mike Muuss) chose ping as the name for the command for checking the status of a network host, it was a moment of inspired genius. The word is almost onomatopoeic in its appropriateness.

But nowadays people are pinging each other all over the place: emails, IMs, even phone calls are â€œpingedâ€ at each other. â€œIâ€™ll ping you an email,â€ they say.

The purist in me cringes a little each time I hear it. But it shouldnâ€™t. The word that was so apposite for those early savants is just as suitable today: it communicates a needed concept. And English, of course, is a living, thriving language. So let people get on with it

Just donâ€™t expect me to use it myself.

Well, on that last, according to the Guardian article:

Jean Rathbone, a celebrant for humanist ceremonies, said opposition to extending civil partnerships came from the â€œmarriage industry and the church.â€

The â€œmarriage industry?â€ I didnâ€™t know there was such a thing. But the term makes sense when you think of the crazy amounts of money people can spend on weddings.

Anyway, onwards. Thereâ€™s a GoFundMe page to contribute to help keep the campaign going. Iâ€™m in.

items.title: Brain Explain
items.content_text:
Interesting article on psychology wherein Robert Epstein tells us that â€œYour brain does not process information and it is not a computer.â€

It is, as I say, interesting. But itâ€™s also profoundly annoying in the way he asserts that the human brain is not an information processor, but then makes no attempt to explain what it is, instead.Â 

He asserts that the brain does not hold a copy of a song it has learned, for example, but instead â€œis changed in a way that allows the person to sing itâ€ (I paraphrase).

But isnâ€™t that just another way of saying that it has stored a copy? If that change does not in some sense denote making a copy, then what exactly does it mean? What is the brain doing when the singer recalls the song? Inventing it anew, exactly (or not) as the original composer intended?

I donâ€™t doubt that what he calls â€œ[t]he information processing (IP) metaphor of human intelligenceâ€ has its limitations; but he has completely failed to explain them or provide an alternative explanation.

The truth is we donâ€™t understand much about how the brain does what it does; and this guy knows more than most of us. But heâ€™s a psychologist. He no doubt has a deep understanding of the workings of the human mind. But I think if you want someone to explain what we understand of the workings of he human brain, then you want that person to be a neuroscientist.

items.title: All the Things in the World
items.content_html:
Do you ever look around and think how amazing everything is? How it all got there? And Iâ€™m not talking about the grandeur of nature, the glory of the universe, and all that. Iâ€™m talking about all the human-made stuff.

I have often found myself in the middle of a city, or looking out of a train window at a bridge or power station, and thought, â€œWow: people built this. Just ordinary people, like me, actually made all this.â€

Look at ancient buildings and you realise that they used to do it without the help of modern machinery, too.

And then think about the infrastructure thatâ€™s carrying these words from where Iâ€™m typing them to where youâ€™re reading them. Hundreds of miles of fibre and copper cables across the country. Thousands of miles of undersea cables. Satellites, and the rockets to launch them.

Weâ€™re pretty amazing sometimes, us humans.

Like I say, Iâ€™ve often thought about this kind of thing. But today, while not at work because Iâ€™m a bit under the weather 1 I had a slightly different version of it.

I had a sudden, overwhelming sense of how much cultural work we have created. Specifically stories and TV and films. Though in fact it was comics that really triggered it.

As I say, Iâ€™m not at my best, so I wanted something simple. I ended up reading a bunch of comics on Marvel Unlimited. And no matter how many I could read in a day, I could only make the tiniest of scratches in the surface.

And in TV, Netflix seem to have a new original series or two coming out every week.

Itâ€™s not all great, of course. But just think of all those people, writing away, acting, filming. Making things.

items.title: Why Are MPs Doing It?
items.content_text:
This is the burning question of the day: why are our elected representatives in parliament behaving like idiots, frankly?

I wrote most of this a few days ago, but the question still stands.

The â€œit,â€ in case itâ€™s not obvious, is waving through the bill to enable to government to trigger Article 50. They did so with very little scrutiny, and without accepting a single amendment. Now as Iâ€™ve made clear, Iâ€™m firmly of the opinion that Brexit must be stopped. But itâ€™s looking increasingly likely that it wonâ€™t be.

We in the populace may have to accept that fact. But members of parliament donâ€™t. They are (or were) exactly the ones who could have stopped it all.

Itâ€™s like thereâ€™s a bus full of schoolkids. The driver has lost control, and itâ€™s careering towards a cliff edge. The driver jumped out and somehow survived. But the kids canâ€™t get off. Luckily thereâ€™s another adult aboard. She grabs the wheel. Hooray, the kids will be saved as she swerves and brakes.

But wait: oh no, she isnâ€™t braking. Sheâ€™s steering more directly towards the cliff, and putting her foot down.

And all the people who could stop her are at best letting her go on, at worst egging her on. Even the ones who said they didnâ€™t want to go over the cliff in the first place.

This simile may be getting out of hand.

items.title: Brexit Hope?
items.content_text:
A very small hope. Brexitâ€”take back control by the improbably-named Jolyon Maugham, suggests that a court ruling could be achieved which would ensure that we can back out of Brexit at the last moment:

The effects of an Article 50 notification are not fully understoodâ€”and not only because May is still peddling a blind bargain, a Brexit pig-in-a-poke. We do know that, should we ask and the other 27 member states agree, we could remain. But it is brave to assume that two years of exposure to the negotiating skills of Boris Johnson, Liam Fox and David Davis will not generate even one hold-out. [...] The preponderance of legal opinion is that we could, after all, decide to remain. That we could, having notified, withdraw that notification. But, given the magnitude of the issue, our parliament must know more than what the answer probably is. It must know what it actually is.
[...]
only the court to which we all subscribe can give an answer: the European Court in Luxembourg.

He/she (Iâ€™m guessing â€œhe,â€ from the writing style) says:

But a case whichâ€”along with Green Party co-leader Jonathan Bartley, Steven Agnew, a Green member of the Northern Irish Assembly and Keith Taylor, a Green MEPâ€”I am bringing in the Dublin High Court seeks to give us the power to travel back if we need it.

And he explains that:

We access it via a national court. And it canâ€™t be one of ours. One of the complaints in the Dublin case is that the other 27 have breached the Treaty by excluding us from Council meetings before weâ€™ve notified under Article 50. And that complaint can only be made by a court in one of those 27. The Irish court is the natural choice

Which all seems fair. The idea seems to be that the European Court of Justice could rule definitively that we could revoke our triggering of Article 50 at the end of the two-year negotiating period. And if the deal is bad, or especially if there isnâ€™t one, parliament is likely to call another referendum in those circumstances, wherein weâ€™ll know exactly what weâ€™re voting for, and get it right this time.

A small hope, like I say. And it doesnâ€™t protect us from the damage thatâ€™s being inflicted in the meantime.

But a small hope is better than none at all.

items.title: Ticket Captcha Fail
items.content_text:
Just tried and failed to book Dylan tickets. Three nights at the London Palladium in April. I got an email from Songkick telling me about it yesterday, and jumped straight on it.

To learn that tickets didnâ€™t go on sale till 10:00 today. At which time I was going to be traveling to Kingâ€™s Cross to get a train to Edinburgh, which is a wee bit inconvenient.

As it happened by just after ten I was at KX, and buying my lunch for the journey. But of course at that time I had forgotten about the tickets. By the time I remembered it was 12:44. The Palladium only holds just over 2000, so there wasnâ€™t much hope.

But I wasnâ€™t helped by Ticketmasterâ€™s ludicrous captcha overkill. Seemed like every time I moved from one page to another I had to click an â€œI am not a robotâ€ checkbox and then select all the pictures containing street signs, or pickup trucks, or storefronts, from an array of tiny shitty pictures. Pickup trucks and storefronts? We barely have the former in this country, and we donâ€™t use the latter term. And sometimes itâ€™s hard to tell whatâ€™s in the pictures. I was doing this on a phone, after all.

I wonder how serious their problem with automated ticket-buying bots is. I guess it must be an issue, given that the whole business of an inflated resale markets and touts at venues still exists.

Anyway, all gone in London, but you may have a chance elsewhere.
On a train to Edinburgh. Snowing at Peterborough. What will happen next?

items.title: "Thread" Dread
items.content_html:
I donâ€™t mind people posting a tweetstorm, wherein they have a lot to say and do so via a series of linked tweets. I think there are better ways to do it; better places to host medium-length pieces of writing,1 but whatever works for you.

And of course I donâ€™t mind other people tweeting a link to the top of the thread and urging others to read it.

But I really donâ€™t care for the habit of doing so while saying nothing other than, â€œThread.â€

I mean, come on, people: if itâ€™s worth linking to, itâ€™s worth writing few words to tell us why you think we should read it.

This post could fit in five or six tweets. I suppose I should have posted it that way. Except #OwnYourContent.
