items.title: The Many-Angled Pub
items.content_text:
I went out for a drink with some people from work last night.Â  We went to a place in Covent Garden called The Porterhouse.

Itâ€™s a very curious place.Â  It extends across three or maybe four floors.Â  Or maybe only two, but with lots of mezzanines.Â  Itâ€™s full of alcoves: everything, it seems, is an alcove.Â  I have no idea, for example, how many bars it has.Â  And in fact, I didnâ€™t go to the bar all night.Â  That, though, is because they have something that is remarkable in a British pub: table service.

Yes, itâ€™s very strange.Â  waiters come and go, collecting glasses and trays, but also, when asked, taking orders and returning â€” very quickly â€” with trays of beers.

So I spent the night drinking Caledonian 80/-.Â  A taste of home, perhaps, but a) it was bottled; b) it was too cold to taste right; and c) itâ€™s been such a long time since I drank it back home that it hardly counts.Â  And I always preferred McEwanâ€™s 80/-, anyway.Â  Oh, and pizza.Â  They serve food, too, and claim a woodburning oven.

It was a good night.Â  But that pub.Â  You know the old computer game that used to say, â€œYou are in a maze of little twisty passages, all the sameâ€?Â  It was a bit like that.Â  But mostly it reminded me of the house in HP Lovecraftâ€™s â€˜Dreams in the Witch-House.â€™

Oh, I suppose the angles werenâ€™t really that wrong; that the walls were quite straight. But there were definitely too many rooms, and bits, and stuff: if not angles.

items.title: Book Notes 5:  Sputnik Sweetheart by Haruki Murakami
items.content_html: The unnamed (though referred to in the back-cover blurb as â€œKâ€) narrator is a slightly-annoying, madly-but-unrequitedly in love with Sumire figure. They met at university. Sumire dropped out to write; the narrator went on to become a schoolteacher.
items.content_text:
I read a review of this book in The Guardian years ago (this one, I think). It sounded absolutely fantastic, and Iâ€™ve wanted to read it ever since. But I only got round to buying it recently.

I was aware, of course, of the danger of approaching a work with unreasonably-raised expectations, so I tried not to. You canâ€™t make yourself think â€œThis wonâ€™t be very good,â€ when you actually think, â€œThis should be pretty good.â€ The trick, therefore, is to convince yourself to have a slight seed of doubt. Iâ€™m not totally sure how well that can ever work, though.

I did enjoy the book, however: it starts with a light, easy style, and has an endearing central character in Sumire. The unnamed (though referred to in the back-cover blurb as â€œKâ€) narrator is a slightly-annoying, madly-but-unrequitedly in love with Sumire figure. They met at university. Sumire dropped out to write; the narrator went on to become a schoolteacher.

Shortly after the start of the book, Sumire, who has until then seemed largely devoid of any sexual or romantic feelings, falls in love with an older, married, woman; who then gives her a job as her PA. Sumireâ€™s love is also unrequited; indeed, unspoken.

Itâ€™s when they go on a business trip to Europe, which culminates in a holiday on a Greek island, that something strange happens.

It is a curious book. Itâ€™s hard to work out what is supposed to have happened to Sumire. It is, until then, so much a realist novel that it is hard to believe that the apparently-fantastic, dream world sequence that is all the explanation we get, is meant to be taken literally.

Then when the narrator, having gone to Greece to help find out what happened to Sumire, returns home to Japan, there is an apparently-unrelated section concerning one of his pupils. He has been having a sexual relationship with the pupilâ€™s mother, so when the boy gets into trouble, she calls him to help. This section really appears to have no connection to the rest of the story,, and no bearing on what happened to Sumire.

So while I enjoyed reading it, on looking back over it, it seems that it is deeply flawed. Or maybe Iâ€™m flawed, because I failed to fully understand it.

I expected that it would inspire me to read more of his work, but it hasnâ€™t: or not yet, at least.

items.title: A discussion of (possibly a rant about) ID
items.content_text:
But not cards, for a change. I was listening to a programme (essentially a religious one) on Radio 4 recently, about â€˜Intelligentâ€™ Design (ID).

It was the second time that day that I had heard SETI pulled in to support ID. The thesis seems to be that, since SETI searches for meaningful information hidden within random noise, it is â€œthe same asâ€ the search for a designer amidst the seeming randomness of the universe. The proponents of ID think that the complexity of the real world means that there must be an intelligence behind it. But the main thing these people need to learn is that complexity does not equal design.

Or not necessarily, at any rate. They are doubly confusing themselves â€” and others, who may be unsure about the realities of science and the tricks of creationists. They look at the search for order among the chaos, and liken it to â€” really, identify it with â€” the belief that order lies behind the chaos.

Letâ€™s put it another way. SETI searches through random noise and attempts to find ordered data, all the while aware that the ordered data may not be there; indeed, to date it has not been. It further proposes that, if ordered data is found, then that may imply that there is an intelligence behind it.

The ID proponents observe the order in the universe and assume that there must be an intelligence behind it; they also see the randomness in the universe, and jump to the conclusion that SETI is doing the same thing as they are.

It is arrant nonsense, of course, but then ID is, from start to finish. Oh, donâ€™t get me wrong: thereâ€™s nothing in the laws of physics, chemistry or biology that precludes the existence of a designer, a creator, a supreme being: a deity, in short. As, indeed, there is no need for science to be incompatible with belief in, or the existence of, a deity. Back when I was a Catholic, I remember one of my primary-school teachers explaining that, while the Bible says that God created the world in six days, a day to God might be a million years to us. Donâ€™t take it literally, in other words.

And therein lies the problem: creationists and believers in ID (who are just very thinly-disguised creationists) take the Bible (though which version, I have to ask?) literally.

Which is a bit like taking any of humanityâ€™s great history of myths literally. Why stop with the Christian Bible, and their strange god, â€œGodâ€1? Letâ€™s take the Norse gods literally, for example. So the next time youâ€™re caught in a thunderstorm, remember, itâ€™s not just the random discharge of static electricity in the atmosphere: Thor is after you.

Or the Greeks: they had some great ones. When you light the gas to cook tea tonight, say a prayer of thanks to Prometheus, OK?

Oh look, we seem to be back at my latest Book Notes post, American Gods. Which makes sense, since it is American fundamentalist Christers who want to foist their god on the rest of their country â€” and by extension, on the rest of the world. By the not-so-subtle device of using the law to control what can and canâ€™t be taught in schools. What is wrong with these people? Have they never heard of the separation of church and state?

Fortunately the US courts seem to be holding the line of sanity so far; but oh my non-existent, speculative all-powerful creator-figure: I hope we donâ€™t get a branch of the Christian Taliban trying to introduce this shite into our schools over here. I have children to bring up, so I have a direct interest in these things.

Letâ€™s not teach our kids to be stupid.

1. As the NME used to say.

items.title: That about wraps it up for freedom
items.content_text:
Start saying goodbye, then, to civil liberties in this country. Oh, maybe not now, and maybe not even that soon; but when the identity cards bill is passed, and the database has been built 1 then the infrastructure will be in place for the worldâ€™s largest ever experiment in social control.

We already have near-ubiquitous surveillance, with constantly-improving automatic recognition: of faces and of vehicle number plates. Add to that the national identity database with its biometrics, and the growing collection of DNA data, and I foresee the potential for a future that even Orwell in his worst nightmare wouldnâ€™t have believed possible.

Pessimistic? Yes, certainly. It may be that the public will rebel against it when they realise how much it will cost, for example. I gather that that is what happened in Australia. But even if they do, once the legislation is in place, how can it be stopped?Â  It seems likely that the best we can hope for there is a change of government. And realistically, that means the Tories.

After all this time thereâ€™s no way on this Earth that Iâ€™m going to put my faith in that lot. No matter that they might have voted against the government on the bill, if they get into power and the act is in force, there isnâ€™t a chance â€” not a chance in all the worlds of the putative multiverse â€” that theyâ€™ll repeal the legislation.

In fact, that is the true nightmare scenario: itâ€™s possible that Blair and Brown are not actually malicious about this, just stupid and corrosively misguided. Imagine, though, what it would have been like if Thatcherâ€™s government had had ubiquitous, mandatory ID and surveillance. Imagine (as Iâ€™ve suggested before) if that had been the situation during the minersâ€™ strike. Or when MI5 were undermining the Callaghan government, for that matter, although thatâ€™s a slightly different nightmare.

And it just goes on and on: the Metropolitan Police are now going to drug-test their own officers. Now, you can safely argue that police officers shouldnâ€™t be under the influence while on duty: but it is a clear violation of their personal liberty, and it just adds to the way in which our national culture is becoming more and more authoritarian. Even totalitarian.

items.title: Drink, Sex and Elections
items.content_text:
How quickly do events overrun the tardy blogger.Â  A few weks ago, when Charles Kennedy went public about his drinking, I started writing a piece about him, and his revelationsâ€™ potential effect on the Liberal Democrats.Â  I didnâ€™t post it that day, and by the following evening things had changed so dramatically that what I said was almost useless as a post.

Later I started a replacement piece, but I never got round to completing and posting that, either.Â  Todayâ€™s by-election victory is slightly ironic, then, considering that what I was originally saying wasÂ  mainly that he really had to resign because he had become an electoral liability to his party.Â Â  Add to that the Lib Dem leadership election and its Shock! Horror! personal revelations, and many would have expected them to do badly at the polls the next time they had a chance.

And then we get Dunfermline.Â  Which suggests to me that the personal affairs of the actual and potential party leadership are minor items at best in the eyes of the voters.Â  And also that people (in Scotland, at least) have had enough of Blairâ€™s repulsive Tory-lite policies, and are (not surprisingly) unimpressed by, and suspicious of, Cameronâ€™s cuddly stealth-Tory aproach.

I hoped, in my original piece, that the Lib Dems would be able to recover from their problems, because theyâ€™re an important force in British politics.Â  Not least because theyâ€™re still the only ones taking a principled stand against ID cards, on which everyone but No2ID seems to have gone silent recently.Â  Now Iâ€™d have to add the hope that the new guy, Willie Rennie, can get himself established in the Commons in time to vote against the next reading of the Bill.

I never thought that, in my life, I would be toasting a Labour by-election defeat, while at the same time bemoaning their privatisation and (lack of) civil-liberties policies; but we live in interesting times.Â  Times in which Britain desperately needs a third force in politics; and it remains the case â€” perhaps more so than ever, today â€” that the Liberal Democrats can be that force.

But I wish they werenâ€™t needed: I want the Labour party back.

items.title: Book Notes 3: Someone Comes to Town, Someone Leaves Town by Cory Doctorow
items.content_html: Or perhaps they are. If so, though then the whole book is a metaphor, and Iâ€™m not entirely sure for what.
items.content_text:
Cory Doctorowâ€™s third novel is his best so far; and itâ€™s strange. Really, really strange.

It is the story of a man whose father is a mountain and whose mother is a washing machine. These are not metaphors.

Or perhaps they are. If so, though then the whole book is a metaphor, and Iâ€™m not entirely sure for what.

Since Alan (or Adam, or Albert, or Aaron) is very different from other people (he doesnâ€™t have a navel, for one very minor thing) it could be seen as about alienation. Alan, however, is not particularly alienated.

His brothers are a different matter, though.

Each of the five is given a name starting with the next letter of the alphabet after the previous brotherâ€™s; but they are not called constantly by this name, either by each other or by the narrator. Instead, they are called by a seemingly-randomly-chosen name starting with â€˜theirâ€™ letter of the alphabet. There seems no real purpose to it. If it is intended to emphasise the brothersâ€™ â€˜othernessâ€™, then it does so: but not enough.

As well as that, each brother has a unique characteristic. Billy, Buddy, Bob (etc) can see the future. Charlie is an island. Davey is twisted, damaged and dangerous. And Ed, Fred and George are a sort of composite being, living inside each other like Russian dolls.

Not surprisingly, one of the subplots centres on one of Coryâ€™s real-world interests: building a free, community-supported wireless network across the city (his native Toronto, in this case). In a way, that subplot doesnâ€™t really mesh very well with the fantastical story: but it does provide a backdrop for it, and it shows that Alan has a life outside of his weird family.

And thereâ€™s a woman with wings. Read it for yourself. Itâ€™s quite amazing, and like his other books, available for free download under a Creative Commons licence.

items.title: Book Notes 2: Cloud Atlas by David Mitchell
items.content_html: And like Nineteen Eighty Four, Cloud Atlas is ultimately a bleak vision, though it contains many life-affirming moments on its way.
items.content_text:
Yes, and only a day after the last one.Â  It took me a bit longer than that to read it, mind you.

A science-fiction book that was nominated for the Booker: amazing. And have no doubt about it: this is a science-fiction book. Just as Nineteen Eighty Four is; and Orwellâ€™s masterpiece is perhaps the best reference point for Cloud Atlas. The appearance of Oâ€™Brienâ€™s Goldsteinâ€˜s book within Winston Smithâ€™s story may well have been a model for Mitchellâ€™s multiply-embedded stories.


And like Nineteen Eighty Four, Cloud Atlas is ultimately a bleak vision, though it contains many life-affirming moments on its way.

The interleaved narratives spread across the history and future history of civilisation, from Victorian missionaries â€˜civilisingâ€™ the â€˜savagesâ€™ of Polynesia, to the Hawaian islanders after the fall of civilisation, trying desperately to hold on to the â€˜Smartâ€™ of the â€˜Oldâ€™unsâ€™.

Each story contains a reference to the the one in which it is immediately embedded, and there are echoes and references across various of the layers: probably many more than I got on a first reading.

Mitchellâ€™s command of the different styles is good, though there are one or two places where it slips, and where you wonder how reliable the narrators are.

I found it slow to get going, though: at first I put this down to not being terribly engaged with the Victorian opening section. Then I thought it was just pacing: the speed of the segments increases, it seems to me, as you work towards the centre.Â  But on the way back out I found the final section, back in the Victorian journals, just less interesting than any of the others.Â  I find the idea of historical novels deeply uninteresting, so we probably have a common theme there.

Also related to the â€œis it genreâ€ question is this curiousity: in the section entitled Half-Lives: The First Luisa Rey Mystery, the title characterâ€™s dead father is called Lester. Lester Rey. Sounds an awful lot like Lester del Rey, the science fiction writer and editor. Of, course, it may mean nothing: but writers donâ€™t choose charactersâ€™ names for nothing, and it sems likely to me that you would at least check that the major charactersâ€™ names donâ€™t relate to any real people.Â  So perhaps Mitchell is suggesting something.

But all of this matters little. What does matter is that this is a damn fine book.

This year Iâ€™m going to try to record all the books I read, and write mini-reviews of them. Iâ€™m not quite going for the "50 Book Challenge" thing, because I doubt that I can actually manage one a week, what with one thing and another. But I ought to be able to get through a few more than last year, since Iâ€™m not doing an OU course.Â  And in fact itâ€™s nearly the end of January, and I have already read three books and started a fourth: so, not too bad, then.Â  Iâ€™m just a bit behind on posting about them.

For Christmas I got volume 1 of A Dance to the Music of Time: A Question of Upbringing.Â  I started reading it on Christmas day, so weâ€™ll have to allow the year to start and end there.

I have been hearing quite a lot about Anthony Powellâ€™s twelve-volume masterpiece recently: there was a whole Radio 4 programme about it, which I heard bits of twice. And I notice John Peelâ€™s Desert Island Discs listing on Wikipedia, recently, and Dance was the book he chose.

So I was keen to read it, despite having seen the TV adaptation a few years ago, and thought it seem very shallow and superficial.

Having read the first volume I find that itâ€™s not at all surprising that a few hours of TV that purported to convert the whole twelve volumes seemed shallow. This thing is dense. The first volume isnâ€™t that long, but it only covers a couple of years of the narratorâ€™s life: the end of school, some time in France, and the start of his university career.

Despite it being set in the years between the first and second World Wars â€” a time that is almost a century away from us, now â€” and the fact that the characters are almost exclusively privileged, public-school and Oxbridge types, their concerns arenâ€™t so far from those of my own student days.Â  Which isnâ€™t so surprising. I suppose: weâ€™re all people, and the state of being a student has always been a rarefied step away from real life.

Anyway, I look forward to working my way through the other eleven volumes.Â  Perhaps Iâ€™ll do them all this year.

items.title: The Rocky Pogue to Brixton
items.content_text:
This was written before Christmas, and is only being posted now.Â  Such isâ€¦ something.Â  My ability to get things done, probably.

The Brixton Academy oozes rock â€˜nâ€™ roll history from its very walls; and a lot of that history is â€” or closely mirrors â€” my own. I saw my first London gig there: The Ramones, in 1987 (and I saw them a few more times there, too, I can tell you). The Sugarcubes spent a bare hour on stage, and it was one of the best hours of live music Iâ€™ve ever seen. The Pixies took the place apart and restored my faith in rock â€˜nâ€™ roll when I didnâ€™t even realise I was losing it. Stiff Little Fingers â€” who were the first band I ever saw live (Glasgow Apollo, 1980) â€” played a farewell gig there (OK, they later reformed, but lets not worry too much about that). At one James gig there, a moshpit full of lovemuppets collapsed on top of me.

But Iâ€™ve seen The Pogues there more often than anyone else.

And The Pogues, it seems, have reformed, and are touring. To Brixton, then, with swisstone. I saw them so many times in the eighties and early nineties that I probably wouldnâ€™t have bothered this time. But back in the summer karmicnull gave me a CD by an American band called the Dropkick Murphys, which I love; and guess who was the support band?

The Murphys take US hardcore (in the punk sense) and Irish (and a touch of Scottish) music, and mash them together in the same way The Pogues first did with UK punk and Irish music two decades ago. Loud thrashing guitars meld with bagpipes and rebel lyrics. There are about six or seven of them, and they move around the Academyâ€™s huge stage like itâ€™s their playground.

That said, and though they rocked mightily, the cavernous space of the Academy did them no favours. They would, I think, be enjoyed best in a smaller venue. About a tenth of the size, say. I found it hard work to appreciate some of the songs I donâ€™t know, so I suspect that if you donâ€™t know their work at all, they would be very hard work indeed, live. Then thereâ€™s their version of â€˜The Wild Roverâ€™. Maybe Americans arenâ€™t as used as we are to every dodgy folk band or drunken denizen of an Irish pub singing this one: but youâ€™d think that when your fortÃ© is speeded up, punked up versions of Irish songs, you wouldnâ€™t do a version of it that is, frankly, plodding.

No matter: Iâ€™ve now heard them do â€˜Fields of Athenryâ€™, live, and am happy.

As to The Pogues: what with one thing and another, I wasnâ€™t totally sure what to expect, after all this time. But I shouldnâ€™t have worried: it was like coming home: both for them and for me.

Let me say this, in no uncertain terms: I donâ€™t think Shane is anywhere near as fucked up as we think he is. Yes, heâ€™s done himself damage over the years, and Iâ€™ve seem him interviewed on TV and been embarassed and wished they had left him alone. But that night, although he moved with something of an Ozzy-Osbourne-esque shamble, he was totally switched on. He didnâ€™t miss a single word, as far as I could tell, and the only mistake he made was that he messed up the first verse of the very last song, â€˜Fiestaâ€™; and thatâ€™s the kind of thing that any singer can do.

Physically, too, he was very together. During one song he kept playing with the mike stand, for example, and seemed to constantly be on the verge of knocking it over: but he always caught it. And at one point he balanced a glass of water on his head.

But what of the music? It was, of course, superb. I say â€œof courseâ€ because The Pogues consists of some of the most talented musicians in rock â€˜nâ€™ roll, and perhaps the English languageâ€™s greatest living poet.

One of their greatest abilities is to make London seem magical, mystic ghostly: songs like â€˜Lullaby of Londonâ€™ is a fine example of this. And â€˜London Youâ€™re A Ladyâ€™ and â€˜Misty Morning, Albert Bridgeâ€™ are hymns to the city that are rooted in more mundane concerns; but they still evoke a lyrical beauty. In a way the effect is not unlike that of Wordsworthâ€™s â€˜Composed Upon Westminster Bridge, September 3, 1802â€˜. Yes, I think Shane McGowan is as important a poet as Wordsworth, all right?

There was a spectre hanging over the show, though: it was nearly Christmas, and it was unthinkable that they wouldnâ€™t do â€˜Fairytale of New Yorkâ€™. But who would sing Kirsty McCollâ€™s part? The song is inherently a duet; there is no way it could be done without two voices.

Tony told me he had heard that Cerys Matthews of Catatonia sang it at the Cardiff gig, but he didnâ€™t think that she was touring with them.

So the end of the third encore and second hour drew close. â€œThis is â€˜Fairytale of New Yorkâ€™â€, Shane growled, to cheers. Then one of the others introduced â€œMiss Ella Finer.â€ One of The Pogues is Jem Finer, as Iâ€™m sure youâ€™ll know if youâ€™ve read this far; so I suspected this was his daughter (and internet sources confirm this).

She wasnâ€™t Kirsty, of course, but she did a fine job. Some of her vowels were on the plummy side (â€œHappy Christmas your arse, I pray God itâ€™s our larstâ€, if you see what I mean): but you canâ€™t hold that against her.

So as far as Iâ€™m concerned, The Pogues are back. Now, letâ€™s just hope they write some new material and put a new album out.

items.title: Freedom Tickling
items.content_text:
Went to see Jon Stewart of The Daily Show on Sunday. He was doing one night in London, with, as it turned out, the executive producer and the head writer of the show.

It was good, though it could cynically be seen as an extended advert for their book, America: The Book. The largest part of the 75-minute show consisted of readings of extracts from the book. Those were enough to make me want to buy it, but the the funniest lines were probably in Stewartâ€™s introductory piece. The final section, consisting of questions from the audience, showed that both he and his co-stars are generally witty and able to think on their feet.

If volume of applause is a measure, though, the highlight of the night for much of the audience was a brief guest appearance. â€œFor this next section weâ€™re going to ask for help from a member of the audience. We picked him before we started, so donâ€™t get up.â€ Then a stocky, black-clad figure walked on. From my position high on the balcony, and with my notedly-poor facial-recognition skills, I couldnâ€™t tell who it was (though Frances, sitting next to me, could). Iâ€™d have recognised his voice, though. Ricky Gervais is officially more popular in London than Jon Stewart (which is not a surprise).

Gervais read the â€œfunny namesâ€ from the book. This is a section on how US newscasters, weather forecasters and so on, canâ€™t have anything like an ordinary name. The authors identified formulas for the name-construction for the various roles. â€œA monosyllabic kitchen-related verb, followed by two unconnected words. Eg â€˜Chop Muddybottom.â€™â€

As further evidence, were it needed, of my poor celeb-recognition, apparently I literally rubbed shoulders with Alan Rickman on the way out; then Frances said, â€œThereâ€™s Salman Rushdie over there.â€ â€œWhere?â€ â€œThere: standing in the middle of the road, with all the people round him.â€

I did even eventually see him, and recognised him. And while I accept that Iâ€™m bad at recognising faces â€” and celebrities in particular â€” I would contend that I just hadnâ€™t noticed him in the crowd at first, and recognised him perfectly well once I knew he was there..

Oh, and the title of this post? â€œWe donâ€™t torture. We like to call it, uh, â€˜freedom ticklingâ€™â€

items.title: On the ethics of modifying blog posts
items.content_text:
What, Iâ€™m wondering, is the etiquette for this?Â  I looked over my last post, on literary deja vu, and I realised that the second-last paragraph was so scrambled together as to be practically unreadable.Â  So Iâ€™ve just edited it, from the frankly execrable:

I did have an experience a bit like this before, though: a few years back I read one of Paul McAuleyâ€™s; Eternal Light, I think it was, but it is perhaps telling that I canâ€™t remember for sure, even having looked over some reviews.Â  It seems I still canâ€™t remember it.Â  It became familar to me in a much more gradual way, and I realised I had read it before.Â  In that case I had the book out of the library, and I figured out that I had had it out before.Â  In this case, with the Cadigan, I have no idea where I got the copy that I originally read.Â  Library?Â  Maybe.Â  Borrowed a friendâ€™s?Â  Always possible.Â  Or did I buy it, and forget? is there a copy filed away in the attic somewhere?Â  I just have no idea.

to the slightly more readable:

But itâ€™s not the first time. A few years back I read one of Paul McAuleyâ€™s novels. It is perhaps telling that I canâ€™t remember for sure which one, despite having looked over some reviews. I think it was Eternal Light, but it seems I still canâ€™t remember it.

In any case, it very gradually became familar to me, and I realised I had read it before. The copy I was reading at the time came from the library, and I figured out that I had taken it out before.

In this case, with the Cadigan, I have no idea where I got the copy that I originally read. Library? Maybe. Borrowed a friendâ€™s? Always possible. Or did I buy it, and forget? is there a copy filed away in the attic somewhere? I just have no idea.

But the question is, should we update a blog post (or a LiveJournal post, if you see a difference) after it has been out there for a while?Â  Obviously in the first few minutes after posting, when you notice the typoes, itâ€™s fine (and I often wonder about people who donâ€™t correct their typoes; donâ€™t they read their posts?)Â  Similarly, if it has been up for months, then you should not edit it in any significant way: itâ€™s part of the fabric of the internet (at the risk of sounding pompous).Â  My concern is when itâ€™s been out for a day or two.

Iâ€™m not really concerned in this case: itâ€™s not as if Iâ€™ve changed the meaning, and nobody has commented on it, so thereâ€™s no concern about comments becoming confusing or misleading.Â  But in general, Iâ€™d be interested to know what people think about changing posts after the fact.

items.title: Literary mind loss
items.content_text:
Iâ€™ve been having a slightly strange, but not entirely unfamiliar, reading experience recently.Â  Iâ€™m reading Mindplayers by Pat Cadigan. Now, I read the first chapter of this a long time ago, in the dealersâ€™ room at a convention.Â  I liked it a lot, and wanted to read on, but the hardback was a bit too expensive at the time.

I decided to keep an eye out for the paperback.Â  And I did: over the years I often checked the shelves for it, but never found it. As far as I could tell, it never came out in paperback, at least in this country.

And all of this was before Amazon and so on, so I couldnâ€™t just search for it. By the time web-based sales were here, I guess I had forgotten about it.Â  Certainly I never thought to do a search for it.

Then in the summer we were in Hay-on-Wye, town of bookshops, for a day.Â  I managed to spend less than Â£30 on books (though obviously I could have spent a lot more).Â 
But, among my purchases, there it was: the Gollancz classics re-issue of Mindplayer.Â  Slightly strange to find that the book has gone from first publication to classic re-issue in my lifetime, but there you go.

Anyway, itâ€™s been high on my to-read pile since then; and I started reading it a week or so ago; alternating it with Charles Strossâ€˜s Accelerando when my Palm is charged.

Now, as I read the first chapter, the fact that it was familiar to me was not at all surprising; I read it at the con years ago, right?Â  But then I got on to chapter two, as you do. Â  Strangely, that seemed familiar too.Â  Hmmm.Â  OK, maybe Iâ€™d read more of it at the con than I thought.

Chapter three: the feeling didnâ€™t go away.Â  Chapter four. Chapter five.

Gradually it became apparent that I had, in fact, read the book before.Â  However, I remembered nothing â€” absolutely nothing â€” about the story.Â  I havenâ€™t finished it yet, and I still have no idea how it ends.

This is a very strange form of deja vu, it seems.

But itâ€™s not the first time.Â  A few years back I read one of Paul McAuleyâ€™s novels.Â  It is perhaps telling that I canâ€™t remember for sure which one, despite having looked over some reviews.Â  I think it was Eternal Light, but it seems I still canâ€™t remember it.

In any case, it very gradually became familar to me, and I realised I had read it before.Â  The copy I was reading at the time came from the library, and I figured out that I had taken it out before.

In this case, with the Cadigan, I have no idea where I got the copy that I originally read.Â  Library?Â  Maybe.Â  Borrowed a friendâ€™s?Â  Always possible.Â  Or did I buy it, and forget? is there a copy filed away in the attic somewhere?Â  I just have no idea.

Itâ€™s the age, I fear.Â  Or maybe someone is playing with my mind.

items.title: He was asking for it
items.content_text:
Iâ€™d like you, if you donâ€™t mind, to join me in a thought experiment.

Consider for a moment, a man: he might be young or old, it doesnâ€™t really matter. Tall or short, dark-haired or fair, dark skin or light; none of this matters.

All that matters is one thing: he is feeling vulnerable as he walks home tonight. He does not project confidence as he walks the dark city streets.

Perhaps he has been drinking: a swift pint or two after work. Not enough to give him artificial confidence, but enough to lower his vigilance, to make him less cautious than he should be.Â  Perhaps not, though.

He doesnâ€™t notice the guys in the shadows; or he does, but doesnâ€™t register the danger. Or again, maybe he feels fear: but heâ€™s got to get home, and thereâ€™s no other way.

Whichever it is, he tries to hurry past them, but the blows begin to fall. He tries to run, but they grab him and hit again. He crumples to the ground and rolls against a wall to get some protection. As the kicks start, he slips into unconsciousness.

Or again, imagine a child, at school. He â€“ or she, their gender doesnâ€™t matter this time â€“ is one of the smaller, weaker ones in the class; or just isnâ€™t as physically confident or brave as some of their classmates. Maybe this is the child of the man above; maybe not.

Bullying happens, of course: and this time it happens to the child we are talking about. Their life becomes hell. And itâ€™s hard to find anyone to talk to about it. Parents donâ€™t understand how bad it is. Teachers maybe donâ€™t want to admit itâ€™s happening.

Maybe theyâ€™ll find help from Childline, or similar. Maybe not.

What these stories have in common should be obvious: both protagonists were the victims of violent crimes.

Now, would you say â€“ would anyone say â€“ that these imaginary, but all too true, characters were in any way responsible for their suffering?

Of course not. No decent person â€“ no-one with even the most basic shred of empathy and human decency â€“ could blame the victim for the crime they suffered.

Yet blame the victim is apparently what one third of British people are prepared to do when the victim is a woman, and the violent crime is rape.

Weâ€™ve got a long way to go.

The discussion on swisstoneâ€˜s journal suggests that the figures could be interpreted differently, and more importantly, that the questions could have been better phrased.Â  But nonetheless, it is a chilling result.

items.title: Post-exam comedown
items.content_text:
Right then.Â  Itâ€™s been a long time.Â  But this morning I sat the exam for my latest Open University course, A210, Approaching Literature.Â  The exam was OK.Â  Hard questions, but good, you know?Â  Each section had several questions that I could have a go at answering, but none that immediately leaped out and said, â€œDo me!â€

As to the course itself, wellâ€¦ Iâ€™m glad I did it, but in many ways I didnâ€™t really enjoy doing it.Â  I think Iâ€™m coming to the conclusion that, while I love reading the novels and the poetry and the plays, I donâ€™t really enjoy reading the textbooks.Â  So I felt during much of the course that I only had time â€” or I only allowed myself time â€” to study what I needed to write the essays.Â  Which is all very well, and I did well in the essays; but it isnâ€™t an ideal approach to learning, and I thought it would (and I think it did) leave me wanting when it came to the exam.

items.title: Today
items.content_text:
Iâ€™m afraid I did what the Commissioner told us not to do: I went in to Central London.

See, I live in Hackney, in the East, but work in Wimbledon, in the South-West.Â  So I was going to have to go into the centre sometime, to get home.Â  I just left work early.

The trains were running into Waterloo, pretty much as normal (but largely empty).Â  Of course, once there, there was no way to get across town: the Tube was closed, and no buses were running in Zone 1.Â  I took to Shanksâ€™ Pony.

Zone 1 is bigger than you think.Â  I guess I knew it extended as far as Angel, but it goes all the way up Essex Road.Â  I ended up getting a bus halfway along the Ballâ€™s Pond Road.Â  It took me about two and a half hours to get home.

Which isnâ€™t bad, all things considered.

Fortunately, the kids were going home from school with a friendâ€™s mum, so they were fine.Â  I left early mainly so as not to leave them with her too late.Â  And of course, to avoid the probable madness of the rush hour.

I am, of course, intensely angry at the scumpigs who would do such a thing.Â  But on a positive note, a lot of people seemed to be doing the same thing as me, and it was strangely pleasing to see so many people walking through London.Â  We should do more of it.Â  And for much better reasons, of course.

I feel I should have more to say, but am blank.

items.title: London bombs
items.content_text: Ian Blair (Met Police Commissioner) is just being interviewed on R4.Â  He says six bombs, and we should all stay where we are.Â  Thatâ€™s easy for him to say.Â  Some of us have to get home this evening (from SW to E London) and collect kids.

items.title: Software patents: dead in Europe
items.content_text:
In other good news, over on BoingBoing, Cory is telling us that Euro software patents are dead:

The European Parliament voted 648 to 14 to reject the Computer Implemented Inventions Directive.

The bill was reportedly rejected because, politicians said, it pleased no-one in its current form.

Responding to the rejection the European Commission said it would not draw up or submit any more versions of the original proposal.

This is excellent news, though as Cory goes on to say,

Software patents have been staked through the heart before, but they keep rising from the grave. Thereâ€™s too much monopoly rent waiting to be extracted by anti-competitive companies for them to simply give up and go home. The price of liberty is eternal vigilance.

A year or so ago the number one or two hit on Google for â€œsoftware patentsâ€ was an article by an old friend of mine, John Gray, who is a Patent Attorney, in favour of them.Â  With well-reasoned arguments, as I recall.Â  Sadly the article appears to have gone now, though links to it remain.Â  Such is one of the weaknesses of the web, unfortunately, when you canâ€™t trust (some) publishers to keep their URLs pointing at something.

Update: asajeffrey found a mailing list post that, if not Johnâ€™s article that I was thinking of, certainly discusses the same ideas.Â  Thanks, Alan.Â  Note that I am not the â€œMartinâ€ referred to in that post.

So, London gets it.Â  I was against it, but now I feel strangely pleased.

I think I was for it at first; I really enjoyed watching the Athens Olympics last summer, the kids enjoyed it, and the idea of having one just down the road sounded great.Â  But then I looked at the plans, and turned against it.Â  The main reason for my opposition was the effects that I think it will have on the Lower Lea (or Lee) Valley.Â  As far as I can tell, our beloved wilderness will be turned into bland parkland, with the associated loss of wildlife habitat.

However, it may not be as bad as all that, and thereâ€™s no doubt that the potential regeneration here in East London â€” in particular the transport improvements â€” could be great.

My other concern is, of course, the cost, and how we taxpayers may be paying for it for decades.

But what the hell: my kids will be 15 and 11 in 2012, so itÂ  should be fantastic for them.

items.title: The afternoon after the morning after the night before
items.content_text:
Well. I did it: I went to the polling place and I put my cross in the boxâ€¦ for the LibDem candidate.Â  Itâ€™s a very odd feeling, you know, not to vote Labour.Â  The only time Iâ€™ve done it before, I think, was in the first London Mayoral election, when Ken Livingsone was an independent.

I think I might actually have given my first vote to the Greens then, and only my second to Ken (knowing that the first vote would be discarded after the first count, of course).Â  And I think I also distributed my London Assembly votes between Green and Labour.

Some of the above suggests that I shouldnâ€™t really describe myself as â€˜a lifelong Labour voterâ€™, which I tend to; but itâ€™s always been Labour at general elections â€” until yesterday.Â  And of course, as I expected, the Labour candidate won.Â  Iâ€™m quite pleased with the overall result, though.Â  Itâ€™s a pity the Tories werenâ€™t squashed like bugs, and the LibDems didnâ€™t do as well as we might have hoped; but at least with Blairâ€™s reduced majority, we might see some reigning in of their madder civil liberties attacks.

And I have Meg Hillierâ€™s email address now, which might come in handy.

The polling place was my daughterâ€™s nursery class â€” four years ago it was my sonâ€™s.Â  I took them both along with me yesterday evening.Â  I usually like to vote first thing in the morning, but I had an early start yesterday, because I was collecting the kids in the evening.

They, of course, had a great time being at school out of hours.Â  I had to wait for ages after voting while they climbed trees.

Then we sat up and watched the results.Â  Well, fell asleep on the sofa from about 12:30 to 3:00, and then watched until 5:00 or so.Â  Itâ€™s been a long time since I went to bed while it was getting light.Â  And on a school night, too.

Update: Jonathan Freedlandâ€™s Guardian blog entry on the ritual of voting says it all for me.

items.title: Things can only get... different
items.content_text:
It seems that my erstwhile MP is more famous since he stepped down than he ever was in action.Â  Unfortunately, his jumping ship to the LibDems doesnâ€™t help me with my â€œNow who do I vote for?â€ dilemma.Â  If Mr Sedgmore was still standing in Hackney South and Shoreditch â€” for either party â€” I would happily vote for him.Â  As it is I have the choice between Meg Hillier for Labour and Gavin Baylis for the LibDems.

I emailed Meg Hillier via her website the other day, and yesterday she actually responded, Iâ€™m pleased to say.Â  You wonâ€™t be surprised to hear that I asked about her view on ID cards.Â  Her answer, unfortunately, was, â€œIâ€™m toeing the party line.â€

Not in so many words, of course; hereâ€™s what she actually wrote (in an attached MS Word document, rather than in the body of the email, for some weird reason):

This is now part of the Labour Party manifesto. I am a Labour candidate standing on a Labour Party manifesto. Had I drafted the manifesto it would have had a different focus on this issue.

Hmm.Â  So are you against it, or not?Â  She goes on to say:

There is a long way before current proposals become law, no doubt there will be an opportunity to influence change as the bill progresses through Parliament.

Fair point, but does that mean youâ€™ll vote against it? And whether it does or not, can we afford to take the risk that such an attack on civil liberties could be passed in any form? To some extent I donâ€™t fear ID cards and the database state under a Labour government â€” even New Labour â€” so much as I do under a possible future Tory government. Imagine for a moment if Britain had had such a setup during Thatcherism, when so many of us were campaigning against nuclear weapons or for the miners, and were generally actively against the government. Or how would MI5 have made use of tools like those, when they were undermining the Wilson and Callaghan governments?

Meg has more modern concerns, though:

I have been told that tackling identity theft and child protection would be better served with some form of ID card â€“ I will be looking into this more.

I have been told that when we die we all go to a big palace in the clouds and have wings, but the baddies are still going to be able to forge or steal the cards.Â  In fact, I think it could make identity theft easier.Â  People â€” or at least, institutions â€” may come to have such faith in database-backed ID cards that the idea of one being in any way wrong will be quite literally unbelievable. The end result will be that, in order to steal someoneâ€™s identity, all you need to steal or fake is one card.Â  They introduce a single point of failure.

The next MP for Hackney South and Shoreditch concludes:

I have no problem with voluntary ID cards.

But itâ€™s only short steps from â€œvoluntaryâ€ to â€œvoluntary but required if you want to use a bank account or leave the countryâ€ to â€œcompulsoryâ€, it seems to me.

Iâ€™m pleased to see that Gavin Baylis is a member of the London Cycling Campaign. Time for an email to him, I think. Followed in a weekâ€™s time by a cross in his box.

items.title: Digital death masks
items.content_text:
Politics not getting anybody interested, then? OK, weâ€™ll try religion.

I was brought up a Catholic.Â  I grew out of it, of course; saw sense, kicked over the traces.Â  But even when I was a devout Catholic, I think I would have found it very strange, to the point of macabre, to queue for hours to see a recently-dead body; and then to take photographs of it.

Indeed, Iâ€™m fairly sure that the Catholicism I grew up with would have frowned on it.Â  That empty shell is not John Paul II, after all: he has gone on, you know?Â  Been â€œcalled homeâ€, in the words of President Bush (pity it wasnâ€™t him.Â  But I digress).

Not that I believe in any of that.Â  I strongly suspect that old Karol has discovered that in the afterlife there is nothing but a purple glow and a humming sound; and that even he isnâ€™t there.Â  If I remember my Vonnegut aright.Â  So it goes.

When my Dad died I went to see his body.Â  At the undertakerâ€™s; in private, with just the family there.Â  It seemed a normal, natural thing to do.Â  Sad, obviously, but a part of saying goodbye, of coming to terms with his death.Â  So I suppose the devout Catholics who are queueing for hours to see the Popeâ€™s body are going through a similar thing; and since he was a public figure, it all happens under the cameraâ€™s glare.

But really: they didnâ€™t know him.Â  He wasnâ€™t family, or a close friend, however important he might be to their faith.Â  So I canâ€™t help thinking it smacks of thanatophilia; almost idolatry; and Iâ€™m sure the church I grew up in wouldnâ€™t have approved.

items.title: The Campaign Trail, 2005: the inevitable fear and  loathing...
items.content_text:
â€¦ but is that a side order of despair with that, sir?

Time to start blogging the election, then.Â  But what to say?Â  Normally Iâ€™d be exhorting you to vote Labour, like in 1997 and 2001; though those were before the days of blogs (for me, at least).Â  But this year.Â  This year itâ€™s different.

I could of course warn of the danger of sleep-walking towards a Tory government, as Ken did.Â  And that would be true: thereâ€™s no doubt that the Tories would be much worse than Labour or the Lib Dems for the economy and public services.Â  Plus the idea of it is just repellent; especially for those of us who lived through the Thatcher years.Â  Who, like me, was politically naive (and fortunately too young to vote) in 1979, and thought something along the lines of, â€œletâ€™s give them a chance to see how they doâ€.Â  And then watched as public services and manufacturing industry were systematically dismantled, as everything good at the heart of this country was attacked by the greedy, money-grubbing scumbags who wanted to turn us into a â€œshare-owning democracyâ€ by selling us the stuff we already owned.

So yes, I could warn about that.Â  About how Michael Howard was one of Thatcherâ€™s henchmen, about how he presided over the â€œNo repetitive beatsâ€ Criminal Justice Act which attempted to criminalise public partying.Â  About how Howard Flightâ€™s secret revelations are probably understated, and that Tory sleaze didnâ€™t go away after 1997, it just went underground.

But this is 2005, and we donâ€™t have to try to depose a sleazy Tory government any more.Â  Itâ€™s much worse than that.Â  We have to try to depose a sleazy Labour government; and we have to do it without letting the Tories in.

There is an obvious answer, in theory, at least: we should vote for the Liberal Democrats.Â  And that wouldnâ€™t be so bad.Â  I could do that (I might have to).Â  But the trouble is, most people, disillusioned as they are with the other two, wonâ€™t vote for the Lib Dems.Â  Many people seem to have this strange desire to vote for the winning party.Â  This is a curious attitude that I have never understood.Â  Obviously youÂ  want your side to win.Â  You believe in their policies, or thnk that an individual is the best person to represent your constituency, so you want them to win.Â  Thatâ€™s how a representative democracy works.

What I donâ€™t understand is the attitude that seems to say, â€œIâ€™m not going to vote for them, because they wonâ€™t winâ€.Â  Well of course they wonâ€™t, if nobody votes for them.Â  But youâ€™re not trying to bet on winner, youâ€™re trying to choose a representative.Â  It doesnâ€™t matter (in one sense) if you lose; it matters that you vote for whatâ€™s right.

The government is crap.Â  New Labour is crap.Â  Itâ€™s not just Iraq and the whole US-poodle thing; I could see my way past that.Â  Itâ€™s much worse than that.Â  itâ€™s ID cards.Â  Itâ€™s house arrest.Â  itâ€™s an attack on civil liberties so extreme that even Thatcher wouldnâ€™t have attempted it.

I live in a safe Labour seat.Â  My MP, Brian Sedgmore, kicked government arse in his speech on house arrest.Â  I could happily vote for him again.Â  Unfortunately, heâ€™s standing down at the election.Â  Iâ€™ve just being doing some research on his replacement candidate, Meg Hilllier.Â  She is worryingly silent on ID cards.

I miss old â€” rather, proper â€” Labour; I miss having people you might actually want to vote for.Â  Hell, I even miss 1997-grade New Labour.Â  I almost miss having Thatcher in power.Â  At least then it was easy to know who to vote against.

But I wouldnâ€™t want them back.Â  Iâ€™d spoil my ballot before Iâ€™d ever vote for those scumbags.Â  Unless â€” just maybe unless â€” they came out against ID Cards.Â  If they did, though, I wouldnâ€™t trust them.

Never mind a Tory government: weâ€™re sleep-walking towards hell in a handbasket.

items.title: Let's rock again
items.content_text:
Burn (tickettothewest) are back in action.Â  Yes, after a gap of only just over four months, we have rehearsed again.Â  Some of you will know that scunner, our former lead guitarist, left to work in Geneva last spring.Â  We quickly spent several months deciding to recruit another old Edinburgh SF Soc friend, Andrew.Â  We then leapt into action at a rate of a rehearsal every fortnight to three weeks.

Or so Iâ€™d have said.Â  A quick check of last yearâ€™s (electronic) diary suggests that our last rehearsal with Ol was in March; and the next rehearsal was in October.Â  Can we really have left it that long?Â  Well, maybe not.Â  We can be fairly sure that the reocord is incomplete, as it only shows one in October and one in November, and I can remember at least three, and I think probably four.

However our most recent was definitely November, which means, as swisstone said last night, that we would increase our frequency if we went to a quarterly schedule.

Given all that, though, last night went surprisingly well.Â  We remembered the stuff well, particularly Andrew, who is least familiar with it, and we sounded good: helped, no doubt, by being in Backstreetâ€˜s best and biggest room, number 1,

In contrast with the plastic chairs of the other rooms, number 1 has two sofas.Â  Not that we used them.Â  Oh no.Â  We were much too busy rocking out to sit down and take a break.Â  Honest.

Still, our workrate is higher than that of the Stone Roses, or My Bloody Valentine. Hmm, except that they released albums at the end of it. Oh well.Â  karmicnull suggests a target of a gig by the end of the decade.Â  I think thatâ€™s realistic, donâ€™t you?

items.title: Rounding up the year so far: still here
items.content_text:
A combination of lack of inspiration, Christmas, and reading for and starting my new Open University course, (A210: Approaching Literature) has made me miss an entire two months of posting. Or almost: I posted about HSTâ€™s death. Oh well, a roundup here, and Iâ€™ll try to do better in future.

The other big time-sink for my evenings recently has been a dangerous addiction. We signed up for LoveFilm, an online DVD rental service, a few months ago, and soon started catching up on something that we had missed when it was first shown, and never wanted to join in the middle: The West Wing.

At the time of writing we have recently finished season four, and it has raised the bar so much on TV programmes that I could hardly be bothered to watch the excellent Desperate Housewives the other day. Actually, I think it may also be that the latter has gone on too long without having enough to reveal, but weâ€™ll see.

I didnâ€™t call you here to talk about TV programmes, though. Rather, I have a few links to post. First, if you were a fan of John Peel and you didnâ€™t hear it on Radio 4â€˜s The Now Show â€” or if you did, and want a copy to keep â€” you should grab A Minuteâ€™s Noise, by Mitch Benn. Itâ€™s the perfect tribute; and in particular a lot more honest than those biographies that were knocked out in time for Chrstmas.

Perhaps I shouldnâ€™t be too hard on them: I did glance over one of them in a bookshop and found it quite moving. But they came out so soon after his death that its hard not to use the word â€˜unseemlyâ€™.

You should all be aware of WriteToThem, by the makers of FaxYourMP; a generalised way to contact your UK MP or other representative (local councillors, for example); and all done as a free software project intended to be easily-transferrable to other countriesâ€™ political systems.

items.title: Gonzo death song
items.content_text:
God motherfuckinâ€™ damn! Itâ€™s like everyone I respect or admire in public life is dying these years. Hunter S Thompson was my favourite non-fiction writer. He was also the most interesting, the wildest, the freeest voice in American poltics â€” hell, in world politics.

Sure, no-one expected him to last even this long, but what business has got dying now, when the world needs him more than ever? And yes, he was a gun nut: but sometimes its good to know that some of the guns are on the side of right.

I always expected to hear that heâ€™d died from one of his favourite things: you canâ€™t die from writing 1; but I always thought it would come from booze, drugs or cars. Or more likely a mixtture of all three. Not guns. And not self-inflicted. Jesus. I expect that weâ€™ll now hear that he suffered from depression, and all the excess was â€˜self-medicationâ€™. I donâ€™t know. But without the excess I doubt weâ€™d have had the writer.

And what a writer. If I believed in religion Iâ€™d say he wrote like an angel; or that it was like his typewriter was wired straight into hades. Instead Iâ€™ll just say that he wrote like his life depended on it, and no-one else could touch the clarity and vision he could achieve.

It was always a kind of comfort to know that he was out there somewhere, pounding the keyboard of an IBM Selectric typewriter, Wild Turkey by his side, slapping page after page onto the mojo wire. No longer.

I guess the going got too weird even for that old pro.

1. Not directly. Not in a democracy. Not in America.2 Though watch out for conspiracy theories over the next weeks and months.
2. Warning: footnotes may contain traces of irony.

items.title: Disrespect the Authoritah!
items.content_text:
I can scarcely believe it. Apparently a film is being made of His Dark Materials; but according to a BBC news story, theyâ€™re removing all references to god and the church!. To paraphrase a comment I read on Slashdot recently, theyâ€™re going to have to fit seatbelts in the cinemas for this one, to stop the audience being sucked into the screen by the suckiness of it.

That report itself says:

The books tell of a battle against the church and a fight to overthrow God.

The film, therefore will tell of nothing at all, it seems. The reason for this is that

â€œThey have expressed worry about the possibility of perceived anti-religiosity,â€ Weitz told a His Dark Materials fansâ€™ website.

Perceived? Perceived? Madness. Yet apparently Pullman doesnâ€™t mind. In fact, it also says Pullman has denied his books are anti-religious. Which, Iâ€™m sure, contradicts everything heâ€™s said before. Incidentally, how do you tell a website something?

In other news, Peter Jackson will be removing all references to the so-called Dark Lord from the Lord of the Rings trilogy.Â  After all, we donâ€™t want to offend anybody, do we?

items.title: Writing, identity, and voting
items.content_html:
Well, I can always blame NaNoWriMo for missing November.Â  I didn’t manage to write 50,000 words, but I did manage 20,000, which I’m pretty damn pleased about; and I’m carrying on with it, too.Â  Maybe by next year’s NaNoWriMo I’ll have it finished.Â  It’s strange how a completely arbitrary, but externally-defined, deadline can boost creativity.Â  In theory I ought to be able to set myself a deadline and get the same effect, but to date I’ve never managed to do so.

If 50,000 is a Nanowrimo, though, I declare myself to have completed 40 Picowrimos.

Other news: in a shock move I am close to resolving not to vote Labour at the next election.Â  If they carry on with their ID cards madness they will have to be stopped.Â  I intend to write to my MP and to the Home Secretary (who has other things on his mind at the moment, which with any luck will distract him from his authoritarian tendencies).Â  The former will only have my vote if he promises to vote against the bill at every possible opportunity (and does so).

It will break my heart to put my cross in the wrong box, as well as exposing us to the danger of another Tory government;Â  but the ID cards scheme â€” and even more importantly, the database that will support it â€” is unconscionable . One encouraging thing I saw this morning was the letters page in Metro: all the letters about ID cards were against them. That’s a very small sample, but Metro is owned by the same group as the Daily Mail. If publishers with an authoritarian right-wing background are turning against the idea of ID cards, then maybe they can be stopped yet. You would expect liberterian right-wingers to be against them, of course. I’m reminded of one of Heinlein’s sayings (probably through Lazarus Long), which I recall as: When a society requires its members to carry ID, it’s time to leave that society. A spot of googling, however, reminds me that it really was:

The No2ID people still have their petition up, so you should sign that if you feel as I do.Â  And write to your MP.Â  Or fax them.

If this paternity/visagate business takes Blunkett down, will he take the ID cards bill with him?Â  I hope so, but expect not.

items.title: Post-teenage memories are pretty hard to beat, too
items.content_html:
He came to Edinburgh, possibly every year that I was there, and me and my mates Steve and Johnny used to go along to Chambers Street Union (now vacated, I read at that link) for the occasion. It wasn’t quite like listening to his radio show, of course, because he didn’t talk that much, and probably didn’t play such a wide variety of records. But what you were sure of getting was a club night â€” or ‘disco’, as we used to call them â€” of absolutely top quality music; and this at a time when the normal club or disco played nothing but absolutely execrable chart rubbish, and had a dress code into the bargain. Some student nights were OK, but once a year there was a night you knew was going to soar.

â€œI’ll play ‘Release the Bats’ if youâ€™ll dance,â€ I remember him saying. He did. We did

One year, when we were sitting in the bar before it started, we saw him sitting across the room, with some people from the union committee. We’d have loved to talk to him, but we were too shy to just approach him. So we came up with a plan. Steve and I were on the committee of the Edinburgh University Science Fiction Society. Why not invent a new class of member, Honorary, to go with the existing Ordinary and Life, and make Peelie one? So we did.

And still being too shy, Steve and I sent Johnny (who wasn’t a committee member, remember) over to make him the offer and give him the membership card.

Though unless Steve always happened to have a few spare membership cards on him (unlikely), we must have planned this out in advance, to some degree. Memory plays tricks. Anyway, Johnny reported that he had said he was happy to receive anything that was free, and took the card graciously. I like to imagine that it still lies somewhere in a drawer at Peel Acres.

The only other time any of us spoke to him was afterwards (and Steve wasn’t there, so it must have been a different year), when we were hanging around outside, and Peelie was loading boxes of records into his car.

Johnny asked him what his real name was (why, I don’t know, and I doubt that Johnny will remember after all these years).

â€œJohn Ravenscroft,â€ Peelie said.

â€œOh, I thought it was something else,â€ Johnny said.

The real triumph, though (and this must have been a different year again, but I can tell you the exact date: 20th January 1985) was when we got a record played for Johnny’s 21st birthday.

The Roadshow fell on the actual day, and at some point, one of us (and it was probably Steve, as I don’t remember doing it (though he won’t either)) went up to the DJ booth with a request. As the night drew to a close we began to fear that he the great man hadn’t managed to get to our request. But then, with only around three minutes left, Peelie said, â€œI’ve got a request here that says, ‘Please play something by The Skids as it’s John’s 21st.’ Well, I doubt it’s really his 21st, and I don’t have any Skids with me, but John, this is for you.â€

And then (at the right speed) came the opening drumbeats of the track that everyone from Radio One to Newsnight has been playing in the last couple of days: â€œTeeenage Kicks.â€

And we all danced. And Peelie went home.

We won’t see its like â€” or his like, of course â€” again.

The only other time any of us spoke to him was afterwards (and Steve wasn't there, so it must have been a different year), when we were hanging around outside, and Peelie was loading boxes of records into his car. Johnny asked him what his real name was (why, I don't know, and I doubt that Johnny will remember after all these years). â€œJohn Ravenscroft,â€ Peelie said. â€œOh, I thought it was something else,â€ Johnny said. The real triumph, though (and this must have been a different year again, but I can tell you the exact date: 20th January 1985) was when we got a record played for Johnny's 21st birthday. The Roadshow fell on the actual day, and at some point, one of us (and it was probably Steve, as I don't remember doing it (though he won't either)) went up to the DJ booth with a request. As the night drew to a close we began to fear that he the great man hadn't managed to get to our request. But then, with only around three minutes left, Peelie said, â€œI've got a request here that says, 'Please play something by The Skids as it's John's 21st.' Well, I doubt it's really his 21st, and I don't have any Skids with me, but John, this is for you.â€ And then (at the right speed) came the opening drumbeats of the track that everyone from Radio One to Newsnight has been playing in the last couple of days: â€œTeeenage Kicks.â€ And we all danced. And Peelie went home. We won't see its like â€” or his like, of course â€” again.

items.title: The time has come to rumble, to inject a bit of fun into politics
items.content_text:
Over the last ten or so years, whenever things have been exceptionally interesting in US politics, I have found myself wondering what Hunter S Thompson would say about it. Usually I wouldnâ€™t find out until a year or so later, when his next book came out.

But now we have the net, and in particular, HSTâ€™s latest article in Rolling Stone:

Did you see Bush on TV, trying to debate? Jesus, he talked like a donkey with no brains at all. The tide turned early, in Coral Gables, when Bush went belly up less than halfway through his first bout with Kerry, who hammered poor George into jelly. It was pitiful. . . . I almost felt sorry for him, until I heard someone call him â€œMister President,â€ and then I felt ashamed.

and:

Richard Nixon looks like a flaming liberal today, compared to a golem like George Bush. Indeed. Where is Richard Nixon now that we finally need him?

If Nixon were running for president today, he would be seen as a â€œliberalâ€ candidate, and he would probably win. He was a crook and a bungler, but what the hell? Nixon was a barrel of laughs compared to this gang of thugs from the Halliburton petroleum organization who are running the White House today â€” and who will be running it this time next year, if we (the once-proud, once-loved and widely respected â€œAmerican peopleâ€) donâ€™t rise up like wounded warriors and whack those lying petroleum pimps out of the White House on November 2nd.

Nixon hated running for president during football season, but he did it anyway. Nixon was a professional politician, and I despised everything he stood for â€” but if he were running for president this year against the evil Bush-Cheney gang, I would happily vote for him.

Thatâ€™s Hunter S Thompson saying that.

Wow.

As a further example of the accelerated time in which we live, it turns out that HSTâ€™s latest book is out: Hey Rube : Blood Sport, the Bush Doctrine, and the Downward Spiral of Dumbness: Modern History from the Sports Desk

Via BoingBoing.

items.title: On having my life back, and academia
items.content_text:
OK, so on Monday I posted the final TMA for my OU course, A103: An Introduction to the Humanities. It was long, and broad, and mostly very good (though donâ€™t get me started about the History of Science block). So now I have my life back: I can read whatever I feel like reading, and not just coursework and the texts Iâ€™m studying; I can write what I want to, and not just the essay for the current assignment.

You have no idea â€” or rather, I had no idea â€” how much reading time a thing like that takes up. I do most of my reading while commuting nowadays, and sure enough, I did most of my studying while commuting. An hour each way makes ten hours a week. Subtract the times I didnâ€™t do that, and add in the other time I spent, and I suspect thatâ€™s about the average time I spent overall: ten hours a week. Which is probably more than I did as an undergraduate 22 years ago. Well, OK, not counting going to lectures and stuff.

Hindsight is a wonderful thing, but these days I frequently wonder whether I did the wrong degree. Iâ€™m glad to have a scientific background, and I donâ€™t doubt that it helped me to get job as a programmer; but recently, given that Iâ€™ve been doing well on the OU course, Iâ€™ve been wondering whether I shouldnâ€™t have done English all those years ago. Maybe, though, I wouldnâ€™t have been so successful at it back then: perhaps I needed the experiences Iâ€™ve had over the years before I could tackle the Humanities with enough understanding.

But I certainly think I should have done Computer Science rather than (or as well as) Physics. I did, in fact, express an interest in doing a half course in CS during my first meeting with my Director of Studies. It wasnâ€™t possible (he told me) to fit it in with the half course in Astronomy that I was doing because I intended to do Astrophysics: they were both in the afternoons (unlike most lectures) and that would have left no time for my Physics lab. I was too shy and unassertive to argue the point; he was too uninterested to discuss alternative possibilities. Note that his role was â€˜Directorâ€™; not â€˜Advisorâ€™ or â€˜Counsellorâ€™. Indeed, I put my failure to study CS squarely down to the failure of the Scottish educational establishment of the time to give me any careers advice worthy of the name.

I accept partial blame for the latter failure, of course. At the ages of sixteen and seventeen, when I had what passed for careers advice meetings at my school, I wasnâ€™t in the least interested in having a career (unless it involved rock â€˜nâ€™ roll); so I didnâ€™t exactly involve myself in my careers discussions. University was just somewhere to go to get away from home, have money, get drunk, and all the usual student things; plus it was what my parents expected (not so much the getting drunk, etc, bits, but you know what I mean). But you would think that they (the careers advisors) could have worked out (or helped me to work out) that the only thing I really liked at school (I was good at Maths, Physics and Chemistry, and for that matter, not bad at English and Spanish, which werere the Highers I did, but I would never have said I actually liked them) was being in the Computer Club, where we learned to program in BASIC.

It really never occured to me that I could study Computers at University. I knew, of course, that Unis had lots of subjects that we didnâ€™t do at school, but I had no inkling of how you would go about starting one. I guess I was pretty unimaginative in that way. There was one guy in my class who was planning to do CS, but he already knew much more about computers than I did (hell, he even knew some Fortran) so that put me off the possibility even if I did consider it: clearly you had to know much more than me to study such things. I wonder what happened to Billy Gibson; the last I heard he had dropped out of Uni.

If I had done CS, I donâ€™t know that my life subsequently would have been that different. I suppose I might have got a job sooner, since Iâ€™d almost certainly have had a better degree; and itâ€™s possible that that wouldnâ€™t have been in London, which could have made a huge difference. But even if that had happened, London had been Calling for a long time, so Iâ€™m sure Iâ€™d have ended up here eventually. The main thing is whether Iâ€™d have been doing a particular philosophy course at the City Lit at the end of 1992. Not doing that would have made a big, big difference.

items.title: Post-election injury report
items.content_text:
Whoâ€™d have thought Tony Wilson would have been so sensible? Just watching the election results on BBC1, and Anthony H was interviewed in a Manchester bar, saying, Stick with what you believe in â€¦ Blair made a terrible mistake in Iraq, and probably even he realises it now â€¦ weâ€™ll get a bloody nose, but weâ€™ll still be breathing. All downright good sense from where Iâ€™m sitting.

Which reminds me, I must see Twenty-Four Hour Party People.

In my last post I mentioned my uninjured right leg, but I realise that most people reading wonâ€™t know about my injury. A couple of weeks ago, on a Saturday morning, I fell down from a raised area in our back garden. I landed with pretty much all my (not insigificant) weight on my left leg. and twisted my knee quite badly. The consultant thinks Iâ€™ve busted my anterior cruciate ligament, but Iâ€™m still waiting for an appointment for an MRI scan to confirm the diagnosis.

So Iâ€™m hobbling around with a crutch and a knee brace, mostly annoyed with myself, because if Iâ€™d stepped more carefully, or been wearing different shoes, it probably wouldnâ€™t have happened. The offending, extra-slippery trainers have been cast out into the recycling bin where there will be weeping, gnashing of teeth, and, hopefully, recycling. But itâ€™ll be a long time, I fear, until Iâ€™m cycling again.

Back on politics, who are these people who, apparently, want Britain to leave the European Union? What kind of madness is that? I mean, aside from the probable contribution of the EU and its predecessors to keeping peace in Europe for the last fifty years, and the advantages I listed here; aside from all that: who the hell do they think weâ€™d trade with?

Theyâ€™ve just announced that UKIP have won a council seat in Hull. Mental. Ooh, the BNP have lost a seat in Burnley. Good.

Iâ€™m writing this on my Psion (surprisingly hard to find a decent link for that nowadays) while sitting watching the TV. Said Psion broke down the other day. I sent it to POS in Streatham to get fixed.. It came back today, and it has turned green (from being black before). There was no explanation, but I assume that what theyâ€™ve done is, rather than repair my one, theyâ€™ve transplanted the guts of it into a reconditioned body. Itâ€™s quite fetching, really.

I like the mood of the discussion on election-night programs: itâ€™s serious, of course, but thereâ€™s a lightness. You get a bit of banter between the presenters and the guests. Of course, it was a lot bleaker during the dark-blue days of the eighties and early- to mid-ninetiesâ€¦

I donâ€™t understand why thereâ€™s so much fuss over the postal ballots this time: we had them for the last two elections here in Hackney (first London Mayoral and local council). This time itâ€™s back to proper polling booths, though. I much prefer it that way. How to increase turnout: let polling go on for, say, three days, and/or make polling day a national public holiday, as someone was suggesting in The Guardian the other day.

items.title: Voting decisions
items.content_text:
It is my custom (or has been at the last two general elections, at least) to broadcast, shortly before an election, to those I know, my thoughts and advice on the forthcoming event.Â  Should the mood take you, you can look back at what I wrote in 1997 and 2001.Â  Back then I did it by emailing a load of people.Â  Nowadays we have blogs.

This time, though, I havenâ€™t managed to get my thoughts out in advance.Â  Then again, itâ€™s not a general election.

Iâ€™ve voted Labour at every election since Iâ€™ve been able to vote.Â  Oh, I think I might have thrown one of my transferrable votes to the Greens in the London Mayoral and Assembly ones last time, but basically its been Labour all the way.1

This time, though, I wasnâ€™t sure.

You know the reasons, Iâ€™m sure: Iraq; ID cards; err, thatâ€™s enough, really.Â  Did I still wanâ€™t to support the part that I hadnâ€™t been entirely happy with since it got the â€œNewâ€ tag?

But what are the alternatives?Â  The Greens, Iâ€™ve been thinking recently, are too luddite for me.Â  Obviously we shouldnâ€™t pollute the environment, and we should do all we can to reduce energy use and carbon emissions; but I fear the Greens are largely anti-technology, and worse, are bordering on the being the type who put animal rights above human rights, which I canâ€™t countenance.Â  Note that I have no hard evidence to hand for either of those concerns, but I could probably find some with a little research.Â  if not, and I do them a disservice, well, Iâ€™m sure theyâ€™ll live.

I thought about the Lib Dems, who are clearly the most pro-Europe of the parties.Â  Iâ€™m sure theyâ€™d be fine in many ways.Â  But in London, for example, they donâ€™t want to increase the size of the Congestion Charge zone.Â  I think it should cover the whole city.Â  Or at least come out as far as Hackney.Â  Anyway, despite my Labour concerns, I was always going to vote for Ken for Mayor again.

I would cut off my uninjured right leg before voting Tory, of course (hey letâ€™s see who says they would scrap the Congestion Charge: Tories, BNP, UKIP; hmmm, is there a common theme there?)Â  And none of the smaller independents really seem to have it.

Last night I decided. and today I went out and voted.Â  Labour, in all available boxes.Â  Because the London Mayor, and Assembly and MEPs arenâ€™t Tony Blair or David Blunkett.Â  And when it comes to the next general election Iâ€™ll probably conclude that Brian Sedgemore, my MP, isnâ€™t them either, and vote for him.

If you havenâ€™t been to your friendly local polling station or postbox today, get on out there.Â  Remember: all those D-Day heroes that were on the telly recently died so that you could.

1. Strictly speaking, voting for Ken for mayor wasnâ€™t a Labour vote, but I think you know where Iâ€™m coming from.

items.title: The post-scarcity tutorial
items.content_text:
In my OU course weâ€™re studying Rousseau at the moment.Â  So at tonightâ€™s tutorial the tutor asked us to, in groups of three or four, discuss our ideal society.

As the good SF-fanarchist that I am, I suggested Iain Banksâ€˜s Culture as a model.Â  Not by name, and I didnâ€™t mention spaceships or Minds â€” we donâ€™t want to raise too many demons at once. I suggsted to the others in my group that a perfect society could only be achieved in a post-scarcity environment, with unlimited resources freely available to all.Â  This led logically to the absence of money and government.

Admittedly I had no mechanism by which this could be achieved, but it was fun to discuss for ten minutes or so.Â  My group (none of whom I know, really) were surprisingly receptive, though the woman who had been taking notes somewhat misrepresented the points we had discussed when we reported back to the class.
It was disappointing how tame the rest of the ideas were; and what was really surprising â€” no: shocking â€” was that one of the other groups suggested increased patriotism as one of the points they wanted.

Thatâ€™s one of the things they wanted in their ideal society.

More patriotism. Really.

I kind of wish Iâ€™d been (and Iâ€™m kind of glad I wasnâ€™t) in that group.
